1.0.title: User Groups Resource
1.0.description: The User Groups resource allows an admin to query which groups a particular user belongs to. The only supported method is query

request.title: User groups schema

queries.description: Query the user's groups

errors.description: Unexpected server error happened during the query

parameters.name: user
parameters.description: The identifier for the user for which the request is regarding.

authenticators.title: Pluggable Authentication Module Classes
authenticators.description:
List of configured authentication modules

The list of configured authentication modules available to OpenAM. All modules must extend from the com.sun.identity.authentication.spi.AMLoginModule class.

remoteAuthSecurityEnabled.title: Remote Auth Security
remoteAuthSecurityEnabled.description:
OpenAM requires authentication client to authenticate itself before authenticating users.

When this setting is enabled, OpenAM will require the authentication client (such as a policy agent) to authentication itself to OpenAM before the client will be allow to use the remote authentication API to authenticate users.

keepPostProcessInstances.title: Keep Post Process Objects for Logout Processing
keepPostProcessInstances.description:
Store Post Processing Classes for the duration of the session.

Enabling this setting will cause OpenAM to store instances of post processing classes into the users session. When the user logs out the original instances of the post processing classes will be called instead of new instances. This may be needed for special logout processing.

NB Enabling this setting will increase the memory usage of OpenAM.

ldapConnectionPoolDefaultSize.title: Default LDAP Connection Pool Size
ldapConnectionPoolDefaultSize.description: The default connection pool size; format is: mininum:maximum

ldapConnectionPoolSize.title: LDAP Connection Pool Size
ldapConnectionPoolSize.description:
Controls the size of the LDAP connection pool used for authentication

Control the size of the connection pool to the LDAP directory server used by any of the authentication modules that use LDAP directly such as LDAP or Active Directory.Different OpenAM servers can be configured with different connection pool settings.

Format: host:port:minimum:maximum

loginFailureCount.title: Login Failure Lockout Count
loginFailureCount.description:
The maximum number of failed authentications for a user before their account is locked.

This setting controls the maximum number of failed authentications a user can have during the lockout interval before OpenAM locks the users account.

lockoutAttributeValue.title: Lockout Attribute Value
lockoutAttributeValue.description:
Value to set in custom lockout attribute

This is the value that will be set on the custom attribute in the users profile when they account is locked.

lockoutDurationMultiplier.title: Lockout Duration Multiplier
lockoutDurationMultiplier.description:
Value multiplied to the Login Failure Lockout Duration for each successive lockout.

This property is used to enable OpenAM to increase the account lockout duration for each successive account lockout. For example: If the lockout duration is set to 10 and the duration multiplier is set to 2; the duration of the first lockout will be 10 minutes and the duration of the second lockout will be 20 minutes.

The default value of 1 disables this function.

invalidAttemptsDataAttributeName.title: Invalid Attempts Data Attribute Name
invalidAttemptsDataAttributeName.description:
The name of the attribute used to store information about failed authentications.

OpenAM can be configured to store information about invalid authentications in the users profile. This allows multiple instances of OpenAM in the same site to share information about a users invalid authentication attempts. By default the custom attribute; sunAMAuthInvalidAttemptsData defined in the sunAMAuthAccountLockout objectclass is used to store this data. Use this property to change the attribute used by OpenAM to store this information.

NB Any attribute specified must be a valid attribute in the data store.

loginFailureDuration.title: Login Failure Lockout Interval
loginFailureDuration.description:
The lockout interval time is in minutes.

OpenAM tracks the failed authentication count for a user over the lockout interval.

For example: If the lockout interval is 5 minutes and the lockout count is 5; the user will have to have failed to authenticate 5 times over the previous 5 minutes for the account to be locked. Failed authentications the occurred outside of the 5 minute interval are ignored.

loginFailureLockoutMode.title: Login Failure Lockout Mode
loginFailureLockoutMode.description:
Enables account lockout functionality for users authenticating to this realm.

OpenAM can track the number of failed authentications by a user over time and if a pre-defined limit is breached, OpenAM can lockout the users account and perform additional functions.

NB This functionality is in addition to any account lockout behaviour implemented by the LDAP Directory Server.

lockoutWarnUserCount.title: Warn User After N Failures
lockoutWarnUserCount.description:
Warn the user when they reach this level of failed authentications.

The user will be given a warning when they reach this level of failed authentications during the lockout interval.
The text of the lockout warning is configured using the lockOutWarning property in the amAuth.properties file.

lockoutAttributeName.title: Lockout Attribute Name
lockoutAttributeName.description:
Name of custom lockout attribute

When OpenAM locks an account, the inetuserstatus attribute in the locked account is set to Inactive. In addition, OpenAM can set the value of another attribute in the users profile.

lockoutEmailAddress.title: Email Address to Send Lockout Notification
lockoutEmailAddress.description:
An email address or set of email addresses that receive notifications about account lockout events.

OpenAM can be configured to send a localisable email message to a set of email addresses when account lockout events occur. The contents of the email message is configured using the following properties in the amAuth.properties file.
  • lockOutEmailFrom : The "From" address of the email message
  • lockOutEmailSub : The subject of the email message
  • lockOutEmailMsg : The contents of the email message

The identity for whom the account has been locked is included in the email message.

The format of this property is:
emailaddress|locale|charset. Multiple email addresses are space-separated.
Email addresses must include the domain name, such as admin@example.com.

storeInvalidAttemptsInDataStore.title: Store Invalid Attempts in Data Store
storeInvalidAttemptsInDataStore.description:
Enables sharing of login failure attempts across AM Instances

When this setting is enabled OpenAM will store the users invalid authentication information in the data store under the attribute configured in the Invalid Attempts Data Attribute Name property.

lockoutDuration.title: Login Failure Lockout Duration
lockoutDuration.description:
The duration of the users account lockout, in minutes.

OpenAM can either lockout the users account indefinitely (until administration action) by setting the duration to 0, (the default) or OpenAM can lock the users account for a given number of minutes. After the lockout interval, the user will be able to successfully authenticate to OpenAM.

authenticationSessionsStateManagement.title: Authentication session state management scheme
authenticationSessionsStateManagement.description:
Specify how the authentication session state is managed.

CTS option will write the state down to the underlying core token store.
JWT option will transmit the state in a JWT to the client.
In-Memory option will maintain the state in the memory (requires sticky loadbalancing).

To configure JWT signing, encryption, and blacklisting use the options in the Client-based Sessions section of the Sessions global service.

authenticationSessionsMaxDuration.title: Max duration (minutes)
authenticationSessionsMaxDuration.description:
Specify how long an authentication session can last.

From the time an authentication session is generated, the session will be invalid after this number of minutes. Values from 1 upwards are allowed.

authenticationSessionsWhitelist.title: Enable whitelisting
authenticationSessionsWhitelist.description:
Enables explicit whitelisting of valid authentication states to prevent replay attacks.

If enabled, each time a response is sent to the user a randomly generated state parameter is also sent back to user. This state parameter is stored accessible to AM and must be sent in with the subsequent request. After a request has been received with a valid state parameter, the next response contains a new state, and the server's view of the valid state parameter is updated.

statelessSessionsEnabled.title: Use Client-based Sessions
statelessSessionsEnabled.description:
Enables client-based sessions.

Client-based sessions provide elastic scalability by storing all session state as a JWT in a cookie stored on the client. It is highly recommended to enable signing and encryption of the JWT in the global session service.

twoFactorRequired.title: Two Factor Authentication Mandatory
twoFactorRequired.description: Enforces ALL 2FA (OATH and Push) authentication Modules (not nodes) only for this authentication realm.

userStatusCallbackPlugins.title: Pluggable User Status Event Classes
userStatusCallbackPlugins.description:
List of classes to be called when status of the user account changes.

When the status of a users account changes, OpenAM can be configured to call into a custom class. The custom class can then be used to perform some action as required. The built in status change events are:

  • Account locked
  • Password changed

Custom code can also extend this mechanism.

defaultAuthLevel.title: Default Authentication Level
defaultAuthLevel.description:
The default authentication level for modules in this realm.

If the authentication module does not set it's own auth level then the module will have the default authentication level for the realm.

usernameGeneratorEnabled.title: Generate UserID Mode
usernameGeneratorEnabled.description:
Enables this mode in the Membership auth module.

When this mode is enabled, if the Membership auth module detects that the supplied username already exists in the data store then a list of valid usernames can be shown to the user, if requested by said user.

loginPostProcessClass.title: Authentication Post Processing Classes
loginPostProcessClass.description:
A list of post authentication processing classes for all users in this realm.

This is a list of Post Processing Classes that will be called by OpenAM for all users that authenticate to this realm. Refer to the documentation for the places where the list of post authentication classes can be set and their precedence.

For example: org.forgerock.auth.PostProcessClass
NB OpenAM must be able to find these classes on the CLASSPATH and must implement the interface com.sun.identity.authentication.spi.AMPostAuthProcessInterface.

loginFailureUrl.title: Default Failure Login URL
loginFailureUrl.description:
Failed logins will be forwarded to this URL

This is the URL to which clients will be forwarded upon failed authentication. Enter a URL or URI relative to the local OpenAM. URL or URI can be prefixed with ClientType|URL if client specific. URL without http(s) protocol will be appended to the current URI of OpenAM.

loginSuccessUrl.title: Default Success Login URL
loginSuccessUrl.description:
Successful logins will be forwarded to this URL

This is the URL to which clients will be forwarded upon successful authentication. Enter a URL or URI relative to the local OpenAM. URL or URI can be prefixed with the ClientType|URL if client specific. URL without http(s) protocol will be appended to the current URI of OpenAM.

usernameGeneratorClass.title: Pluggable User Name Generator Class
usernameGeneratorClass.description:
The name of the default implementation of the user name generator class.

The name of the class used to return a list of usernames to the Membership auth module.

NB This class must implement the interface com.sun.identity.authentication.spi.UserIDGenerator

userAttributeSessionMapping.title: User Attribute Mapping to Session Attribute
userAttributeSessionMapping.description:
Mapping of user profile attribute name to session attribute name.

The setting causes OpenAM to read the named attributes from the users profile in the data store and store their values in the users session.

Format: User Profile Attribute|Session Attribute name.

zeroPageLoginReferrerWhiteList.title: Zero Page Login Referer Whitelist
zeroPageLoginReferrerWhiteList.description:
List of allowed HTTP Referer (sic) URLs from which Zero Page Login requests are allowed.

Enter here all URLs from which you want to allow Zero Page Login. This provides some mitigation against Login CSRF attacks. Leave empty to allow from any Referer. Applies to both GET and POST login requests.

moduleBasedAuthEnabled.title: Module Based Authentication
moduleBasedAuthEnabled.description:
Allows a user to authenticate via module based authentication.

The feature allow users to override the realm configuration and use a named authentication module to authenticate.

NB Recommended to turn this feature off in production environments.

keyAlias.title: Persistent Cookie Encryption Certificate Alias
keyAlias.description:
Keystore Alias for encrypting Persistent Cookies.

This is the alias for the private/public keys in the Keystore used in Persistent Cookie authentication requests.

zeroPageLoginAllowedWithoutReferrer.title: Zero Page Login Allowed without Referer?
zeroPageLoginAllowedWithoutReferrer.description:
Whether to allow Zero Page Login if the HTTP Referer header is missing.

The HTTP Referer header is sometimes missing from requests (e.g., if making a request to HTTP from HTTPS). This setting controls whether such requests should be allowed or not. Setting to 'true' will reduce the risk of Login CSRF attacks with Zero Page Login, but may potentially deny legitimate requests.

sharedSecret.title: Organization Authentication Signing Secret
sharedSecret.description:
HMAC shared secret for signing RESTful Authentication requests.

This is the shared secret for signing state used in RESTful authentication requests. Should be at Base-64 encoded and at least 128-bits in length. By default a cryptographically secure random value is generated.

zeroPageLoginEnabled.title: Zero Page Login
zeroPageLoginEnabled.description:
Allows a user to authenticate using GET request parameters without showing the login screen.

Enable this feature if the authentication mechanism uses a single authentication screen or the first authentication screen should always be invisible to users (since it is auto-submitted). Use caution when enabling this feature as it can be used to authenticate using regular GET parameters, which could be cached by browsers and logged in server and proxy access logs exposing the values of the GET parameters.

defaultRole.title: User Profile Dynamic Creation Default Roles
defaultRole.description:
List of roles of which dynamically created users will be a member.

Enter the DN for each role that will be assigned to a new user when their profile has been dynamically created by OpenAM.

NB Deprecated functionality in OpenAM.

dynamicProfileCreation.title: User Profile
dynamicProfileCreation.description:
Controls the result of the user profile success post successful authentication.

Controls whether a user profile is required for authentication to be successful or if the profile will be dynamically created if none already exists. Choose ignore if you do not have a data store configured in the realm.

aliasAttributeName.title: Alias Search Attribute Name
aliasAttributeName.description:
The secondary LDAP attribute retrieves the user profile if the primary LDAP attribute specified in 'User Naming Attribute' fails.

This list of LDAP attributes is used to extend the set of attributes searched by OpenAM to find the users profile.
For example:
  • cn
  • mail
  • givenname

A user authenticates to OpenAM under the id of steve, OpenAM will first search using the naming attribute (uid by default) so uid=steve, if no match is found then cn=steve will be searched until a match is found or the list is exhausted.


NB Only used when User Profile searching is enabled.

adminAuthModule.title: Administrator Authentication Configuration
adminAuthModule.description:
Default Authentication Service for administrators

This is the authentication service that will be used to authentication administrative users to this realm.

orgConfig.title: Organization Authentication Configuration
orgConfig.description:
Default Authentication Service for users

This is the authentication service that will be used to authenticate users to this realm.

validGotoDestinations.title: Valid goto URL Resources
validGotoDestinations.description:
List of valid goto URL resources.

OpenAM's default behavior after login or logout is to redirect the user to the URL specified in the goto or gotoOnFail query string parameters supplied to the authentication interface during login or logout.

To enhance security, a list of valid URL resources can be specified here so OpenAM can validate the goto and gotoOnFail URL against them.

OpenAM will only redirect a user after login or logout if the URL matches any of the resources specified in this property. If the URL does not match, the user is redirected to either the user profile page or administration console after login, or the logged out page after logout. If this property is not set, it is assumed that all redirect URLs are valid.

The resources defined here can have the * wildcard defined, which matches all characters except ?. Example values for this setting:

  • http://app.example.com:80/*
  • http://app.example.com:80/*?*

actions.description: Obtain the collection of all secondary configuration types related to the resource.
actions.name: getAllTypes

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-auth-kba-attemp.title: Knowledge Based Authentication Attempts Attribute Name

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-proxied-auth-enable.title: Proxied Authorization using Bind DN
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-proxied-auth-enable.description: Enable this setting if you have configured the LDAP bind DN account for proxied authorization (DS proxied-auth privilege). Do not enable this property if the LDAP bind DN account does not have the proxied-auth privilege granted because the user would not be able to reset their password. DS and AM log an error when this occurs.

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-timeunit.title: LDAP Connection Heartbeat Time Unit
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-timeunit.description:
Defines the time unit corresponding to the Heartbeat Interval setting.

This setting controls how often OpenAM should send a heartbeat search request to the configured directory. If a connection becomes unresponsive (e.g. due to a network error) then it may take up to the interval period before the problem is detected. Use along with the Heartbeat Interval parameter to define the exact interval.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-ldap-server.title: LDAP Server
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-ldap-server.description: Format: LDAP server host name:port | server_ID | site_ID

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-interval.title: LDAP Connection Heartbeat Interval
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-interval.description:
Specifies how often should OpenAM send a heartbeat request to the directory.

This setting controls how often OpenAM should send a heartbeat search request to the configured directory. If a connection becomes unresponsive (e.g. due to a network error) then it may take up to the interval period before the problem is detected. Use along with the Heartbeat Time Unit parameter to define the exact interval. Zero or negative value will result in disabling heartbeat requests.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-connection-mode.title: LDAP Connection Mode
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-connection-mode.description:
Defines which protocol/operation is used to establish the connection to the LDAP Directory Server.

If 'LDAP' is selected, the connection won't be secured and passwords are transferred in cleartext over the network.
If 'LDAPS' is selected, the connection is secured via SSL or TLS.
If 'StartTLS' is selected, the connection is secured by using StartTLS extended operation.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-authid.title: LDAP Bind DN
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-authid.description: A user or admin with sufficient access rights to perform the supported operations.

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-behera-support-enab.title: Behera Support Enabled
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-behera-support-enab.description: When enabled, Behera draft control will be used in the outgoing requests for operations that may modify password value. This will allow OpenAM to display password policy related error messages when password policies are not met.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-size.title: DN Cache Size
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-size.description: In DN items, only used when DN Cache is enabled.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-enabled.title: DN Cache
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-enabled.description:
Used to enable/disable the DN Cache within the OpenAM repository implementation.

The DN Cache is used to cache DN lookups which tend to happen in bursts during authentication. The DN Cache can become out of date when a user is moved or renamed in the underlying LDAP store and this is not reflected in a persistent search result. Enable when the underlying LDAP store supports persistent search and move/rename (mod_dn) results are available.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-memberurl.title: Attribute Name of Group Member URL

sunIdRepoSupportedOperations.title: LDAPv3 Plug-in Supported Types and Operations

_id.title: ID

additionalProperties.title: Other properties
additionalProperties.description: Any additional properties for the item (varies based on the schema of the type)

frOathOtpMaxRetry.title: One Time Password Max Retry
frOathOtpMaxRetry.description: The number of times entry of the OTP may be attempted. Minimum is 1 maximum is 10 and default is 3.

oathIssuerName.title: Name of the Issuer
oathIssuerName.description: Name to identify the OTP issuer.

totpTimeStepsInWindow.title: TOTP Time Steps
totpTimeStepsInWindow.description:
The number of time steps to check before and after receiving a OTP.

This is the number of time step intervals to check the received OTP against both forward in time and back in time. For example, with 1 time steps and a time step interval of 30 seconds the server will allow a code between the previous code, the current code and the next code.

addChecksumToOtpEnabled.title: Add Checksum Digit
addChecksumToOtpEnabled.description:
This adds a checksum digit to the OTP.

This adds a digit to the end of the OTP generated to be used as a checksum to verify the OTP was generated correctly. This is in addition to the actual password length. You should only set this if your device supports it.

totpMaximumClockDrift.title: Maximum Allowed Clock Drift
totpMaximumClockDrift.description: Number of time steps a client is allowed to get out of sync with the server before manual resynchronisation is required. For example, with 3 allowed drifts and a time step interval of 30 seconds the server will allow codes from up to 90 seconds from the current time to be treated as the current time step. The drift for a user's device is calculated each time they enter a new code. If the drift exceeds this value, the user's authentication code will be rejected.

authenticationLevel.title: Authentication Level
authenticationLevel.description:
The authentication level associated with this module.

Each authentication module has an authentication level that can be used to indicate the level of security associated with the module; 0 is the lowest (and the default).

passwordLength.title: One Time Password Length
passwordLength.description: The length of the generated OTP in digits, must be at least 6 and compatible with the hardware/software OTP generators you expect your end-users to use. For example, Google and ForgeRock authenticators support values of 6 and 8.

minimumSecretKeyLength.title: Minimum Secret Key Length
minimumSecretKeyLength.description: Number of hexadecimal characters allowed for the Secret Key.

truncationOffset.title: Truncation Offset
truncationOffset.description:
This adds an offset to the generation of the OTP.

This is an option used by the HOTP algorithm that not all devices support. This should be left default unless you know your device uses a offset.

totpTimeStepInterval.title: TOTP Time Step Interval
totpTimeStepInterval.description:
The TOTP time step in seconds that the OTP device uses to generate the OTP.

This is the time interval that one OTP is valid for. For example, if the time step is 30 seconds, then a new OTP will be generated every 30 seconds. This makes a single OTP valid for only 30 seconds.

oathAlgorithm.title: OATH Algorithm to Use
oathAlgorithm.description:
Choose the algorithm your device uses to generate the OTP.

HOTP uses a counter value that is incremented every time a new OTP is generated. TOTP generates a new OTP every few seconds as specified by the time step interval.

hotpWindowSize.title: HOTP Window Size
hotpWindowSize.description:
The size of the window to resynchronize with the client.

This sets the window that the OTP device and the server counter can be out of sync. For example, if the window size is 100 and the servers last successful login was at counter value 2, then the server will accept a OTP from the OTP device that is from device counter 3 to 102.

1.0.title: Policies
1.0.description: The Policy resource endpoint is responsible for managing policies. The available operations are create, read, update, delete, query, evalute action, evaluate tree action. Policies are realm specific, hence the URI for the policies API can contain a realm component. If the realm is not specified in the URI, the top level realm is used.

The two resource types should have the same resource patterns

2.0.title: Policies
2.0.description: The Policy resource endpoint is responsible for managing policies. The available operations are create, read, update, delete, query, evalute action, evaluate tree action. Policies are realm specific, hence the URI for the policies API can contain a realm component. If the realm is not specified in the URI, the top level realm is used.

pathParameter.name: resourceId
pathParameter.description: The unique identifier of the policy

kerberosRealm.title: Kerberos Realm
kerberosRealm.description: The name of the Kerberos (Active Directory) realm used for authentication

principalName.title: Service Principal
principalName.description:
The name of the Kerberos principal used during authentication

This principal must match the name used in the keytab file created from the Active Directory server.
The format of the field is as follows:

HTTP/openam.forgerock.com@AD_DOMAIN.COM

authenticationLevel.title: Authentication Level
authenticationLevel.description:
The authentication level associated with this module.

Each authentication module has an authentication level that can be used to indicate the level of security associated with the module; 0 is the lowest (and the default).

lookupUserInRealm.title: Search for the user in the realm
lookupUserInRealm.description:
Validate that the user has a matched user profile configured in the data store.

If this option is enabled, the module validates whether the account corresponds to a user profile in the Data Store for the realm. The attributes to perform the search are configured under Access Control > Realm Name > Authentication > All Core settings > Alias Search Attribute Name.

kerberosServerName.title: Kerberos Server Name
kerberosServerName.description: The hostname/IP address of the Kerberos (Active Directory) server.

kerberosServiceIsinitiator.title: isInitiator
kerberosServiceIsinitiator.description: Configuration used for JDK Kerbrose LoginModule. True, if initiator. False, if acceptor only. Default is true

trustedKerberosRealms.title: Trusted Kerberos realms
trustedKerberosRealms.description:
List of trusted Kerberos realms for User Kerberos tickets.

If realms are configured, then Kerberos tickets are only accepted if the realm part of the UserPrincipalName of the Users Kerberos ticket matches a realm from the list.

keytabFileName.title: Keytab File Name
keytabFileName.description:
The path of the AD keytab file

This is the absolute pathname of the AD keytab file. The keytab file is generated by the Active Directory server.

returnPrincipalWithDomainName.title: Return Principal with Domain Name
returnPrincipalWithDomainName.description: Returns the fully qualified name of the authenticated user rather than just the username.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-memberurl.title: Attribute Name of Group Member URL

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-auth-kba-attemp.title: Knowledge Based Authentication Attempts Attribute Name

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-timeunit.title: LDAP Connection Heartbeat Time Unit
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-timeunit.description:
Defines the time unit corresponding to the Heartbeat Interval setting.

This setting controls how often OpenAM should send a heartbeat search request to the configured directory. If a connection becomes unresponsive (e.g. due to a network error) then it may take up to the interval period before the problem is detected. Use along with the Heartbeat Interval parameter to define the exact interval.

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-interval.title: LDAP Connection Heartbeat Interval
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-interval.description:
Specifies how often should OpenAM send a heartbeat request to the directory.

This setting controls how often OpenAM should send a heartbeat search request to the configured directory. If a connection becomes unresponsive (e.g. due to a network error) then it may take up to the interval period before the problem is detected. Use along with the Heartbeat Time Unit parameter to define the exact interval. Zero or negative value will result in disabling heartbeat requests.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-connection-mode.title: LDAP Connection Mode
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-connection-mode.description:
Defines which protocol/operation is used to establish the connection to the LDAP Directory Server.

If 'LDAP' is selected, the connection won't be secured and passwords are transferred in cleartext over the network.
If 'LDAPS' is selected, the connection is secured via SSL or TLS.
If 'StartTLS' is selected, the connection is secured by using StartTLS extended operation.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-ldap-server.title: LDAP Server
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-ldap-server.description: Format: LDAP server host name:port | server_ID | site_ID

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-authid.title: LDAP Bind DN
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-authid.description: A user or admin with sufficient access rights to perform the supported operations.

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-behera-support-enab.title: Behera Support Enabled
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-behera-support-enab.description: When enabled, Behera draft control will be used in the outgoing requests for operations that may modify password value. This will allow OpenAM to display password policy related error messages when password policies are not met.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-enabled.title: DN Cache
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-enabled.description:
Used to enable/disable the DN Cache within the OpenAM repository implementation.

The DN Cache is used to cache DN lookups which tend to happen in bursts during authentication. The DN Cache can become out of date when a user is moved or renamed in the underlying LDAP store and this is not reflected in a persistent search result. Enable when the underlying LDAP store supports persistent search and move/rename (mod_dn) results are available.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-size.title: DN Cache Size
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-size.description: In DN items, only used when DN Cache is enabled.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-nsrolefilter.title: Attribute Name of Filtered Role Filter

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-nsrole.title: Attribute Name for Filtered Role Membership

sunIdRepoSupportedOperations.title: LDAPv3 Plug-in Supported Types and Operations

appleLink.description: URL of the app to download on the App Store.

issuer.title: Issuer Name
issuer.description: The Name of the service as it will appear on the registered device.

googleLink.title: Google Play URL
googleLink.description: URL of the app to download on Google Play.

authenticationLevel.title: Authentication Level
authenticationLevel.description:
The authentication level associated with this module.

Each authentication module has an authentication level that can be used to indicate the level of security associated with the module; 0 is the lowest (and the default).

imgUrl.title: Image URL
imgUrl.description: The location of the image to download and display as your identity issuer's logo within the mobile app.

bgcolour.title: Background Colour
bgcolour.description: The background colour of the image to display behind your identity issuer's logo within the mobile app.

timeoutInMilliSecconds.title: Registration Response Timeout (ms)
timeoutInMilliSecconds.description: The period of time (in milliseconds) within which the registration QR code should be replied to.

otpMaxRetry.description: The number of times entry of the OTP may be attempted. Minimum is 1 maximum is 10 and default is 3.

userProfileTelephoneAttribute.title: Mobile Phone Number Attribute Name

smtpSslEnabled.title: Mail Server Secure Connection
smtpSslEnabled.description: This setting controls whether the authentication module communicates with the mail server using SSL/TLS

smtpUserPassword.title: Mail Server Authentication Password
smtpUserPassword.description: The password to use if the mail server is using SMTP authentication

smtpFromAddress.title: Email From Address
smtpFromAddress.description: Emails from the HOTP Authentication module will come from this address.

smtpUsername.title: Mail Server Authentication Username
smtpUsername.description: The username to use if the mail server is using SMTP authentication

smsGatewayClass.title: SMS Gateway Implementation Class
smsGatewayClass.description:
The HOTP authentication module uses this class to send SMS messages.

The SMS gateway class must implement the following interface

com.sun.identity.authentication.modules.hotp.SMSGateway

otpValidityDuration.title: One Time Password Validity Length
otpValidityDuration.description: This One Time Password will remain valid for this period (in minutes)

otpDeliveryMethod.title: One Time Password Delivery
otpDeliveryMethod.description: The mechanism used to deliver the One Time Password

smtpHostPort.title: Mail Server Host Port
smtpHostPort.description:
The port of the mail server.

The default port for SMTP is 25, if using SSL the default port is 465.

autoSendOTP.title: Auto Send OTP Code
autoSendOTP.description: Select this checkbox if the OTP should be sent automatically

otpLength.title: One Time Password Length
otpLength.description: The length of the generated One Time Password (in digits)

mobileCarrierAttribute.title: Mobile Carrier Attribute Name
mobileCarrierAttribute.description: This is the attribute name used for a mobile carrier domain for sending SMS messages

userProfileEmailAttribute.title: Email Attribute Name
userProfileEmailAttribute.description: This is the attribute name used by the OTP to email the user

smtpHostname.title: Mail Server Host Name
smtpHostname.description: The name of the mail server; OpenAM will use SMTP to send the messages.

authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.title: Key Store Type
authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.description:
Type of key store to load.

Note: PKCS#11 key stores require hardware support such as a security device or smart card and is not available by default in most JVM installations.

See the JDK 8 PKCS#11 Reference Guide for more details.

authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.title: Device Profile Encryption Scheme
authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.description:
Encryption scheme to use to secure device profiles stored on the server.

If enabled, each device profile is encrypted using a unique random secret key using the given strength of AES encryption in CBC mode with PKCS#5 padding. An HMAC-SHA of the given strength (truncated to half-size) is used to ensure integrity protection and authenticated encryption. The unique random key is encrypted with the given RSA key pair and stored with the device profile.

Note: AES-256 may require installation of the JCE Unlimited Strength policy files.

authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.title: Encryption Key Store
authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.description: Path to the key store from which to load encryption keys.

authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.title: Key Store Password
authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.description: Password to unlock the key store. This password is encrypted when it is saved in the OpenAM configuration. You should modify the default value.

pushAttrName.title: Profile Storage Attribute
pushAttrName.description:
The user's attribute in which to store Push Notification profiles.

The default attribute is added to the schema when you prepare a user store for use with OpenAM. If you want to use a different attribute, you must make sure to add it to your user store schema prior to deploying push notifications with the ForgeRock Authenticator app in OpenAM. OpenAM must be able to write to the attribute.

authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.title: Key-Pair Alias
authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.description: Alias of the certificate and private key in the key store. The private key is used to encrypt and decrypt device profiles.

authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.title: Private Key Password
authenticatorPushDeviceSettingsEncryptio.description: Password to unlock the private key.

authenticatorPushSkippableName.title: ForgeRock Authenticator (Push) Device Skippable Attribute Name
authenticatorPushSkippableName.description: Name of the attribute on a user's profile used to store their selection of whether to skip ForgeRock Authenticator (Push) 2FA modules.

idTokenHeaderName.title: Name of header referencing the ID Token

accountProviderClass.title: Account provider class
accountProviderClass.description:
Name of the class implementing the account provider.

This class is used by the module to find the account from the attributes mapped by the Account Mapper org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.AccountProvider interface.

cryptoContextType.title: OpenID Connect validation configuration type
cryptoContextType.description: Please select either 1. the issuer discovery url, 2. the issuer jwk url, or 3. the client_secret.

cryptoContextValue.title: OpenID Connect validation configuration value
cryptoContextValue.description:
The discovery url, or jwk url, or the client_secret, corresponding to the selection above.

If discovery or jwk url entered, entry must be in valid url format,
e.g. https://accounts.google.com/.well-known/openid-configuration
NB If client_secret entered, entry is ignored and the value of the Client Secret is used.

jwtToLdapAttributeMappings.title: Mapping of jwt attributes to local LDAP attributes
jwtToLdapAttributeMappings.description:
Format: jwt_attribute=local_ldap_attribute

Mappings allow jwt entries to drive principal lookup. This entry determines how to translate between local LDAP attributes and the entries in the jwt. See OpenID Connect Core 1.0 Specification section 5.4 on how to request the inclusion of additional attributes in issued ID Tokens.

principalMapperClass.title: Principal mapper class
principalMapperClass.description:
Class which implements mapping of jwt state to a Principal in the local identity repository

Any custom implementation must implement the org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.AttributeMapper interface.

clientSecret.title: Client Secret
clientSecret.description:
OAuth client_secret parameter

For more information on the OAuth client_secret parameter refer to the RFC 6749, section 2.3.1

acceptedAuthorizedParties.title: List of accepted authorized parties
acceptedAuthorizedParties.description:
A list of case sensitive strings which can be either string or URI values

A list of authorized parties which this module will accept ID tokens from. This will be checked against the authorized party claim of the ID token.

audienceName.title: Audience name
audienceName.description:
A case sensitive string

The audience name for this OpenID Conenct module. This will be used to check that the ID token received is intended for this module as an audience.

useSubClaimIfNoMatch.title: Use "sub" claim if no match
useSubClaimIfNoMatch.description: If no account is found that matches, whether to use the "sub" claim as the principal name or (if false) to fail.

idTokenIssuer.title: Name of OpenID Connect ID Token Issuer
idTokenIssuer.description: Value must match the iss field in issued ID Token

authenticatorAttachment.title: Authentication attachment
authenticatorAttachment.description: If specified, the authenticators will be filtered out that don't match the attachment type. A PLATFORM authenticator is part of the device, and CROSS_PLATFORM authenticator can be removed from a device and used elsewhere, e.g. via USB.

excludeCredentials.title: Limit registrations
excludeCredentials.description: If enabled, each authenticator may only be registered against a user's profile once.

generateRecoveryCodes.title: Generate recovery codes
generateRecoveryCodes.description: If enabled, the success outcome's transient state will contain a set of recovery codes. If this success outcome is passed into a Recovery Code Display Node, these codes will be presented to the user. A user may use recovery codes to bypass the WebAuthn authentication node in the event they have lost their authenticator. A set of recovery codes is shared among all registered WebAuthn authenticators, with the latest-generated set being the only valid set of codes.

userVerificationRequirement.title: User verification requirement
userVerificationRequirement.description: If specified as REQUIRED, authenticators that don't verify user identity are filtered out and should not be selectable by the user.

timeout.title: Timeout
timeout.description: The number of seconds to wait for a valid WebAuthn authenticator to be registered before failing.

relyingPartyDomain.title: Relying party identifier
relyingPartyDomain.description: The domain against which to register devices, if blank AM will make a best guess at the domain.

relyingPartyName.title: Relying party
relyingPartyName.description: The name of the Relying Party to present, this could be the name of the organisation, realm, etc.

adRecursiveGroupMembership.title: AD Recursive Group Membership Evaluation
adRecursiveGroupMembership.description:
Used to enable/disable Active Directory Recursive Group Membership evaluation.

Enables an Active Directory specific extensible filter called LDAP_MATCHING_RULE_IN_CHAIN that according to MSDN "walks the chain of ancestry in objects all the way to the root until it finds a match", meaning that it will resolve all group memberships, including nested groups. This will add a performance overhead on the Active Directory server, indexes may need to be created.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-auth-kba-attemp.title: Knowledge Based Authentication Attempts Attribute Name

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-authid.title: LDAP Bind DN
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-authid.description: A user or admin with sufficient access rights to perform the supported operations.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-ldap-server.title: LDAP Server
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-ldap-server.description: Format: LDAP server host name:port | server_ID | site_ID

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-interval.title: LDAP Connection Heartbeat Interval
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-interval.description:
Specifies how often should OpenAM send a heartbeat request to the directory.

This setting controls how often OpenAM should send a heartbeat search request to the configured directory. If a connection becomes unresponsive (e.g. due to a network error) then it may take up to the interval period before the problem is detected. Use along with the Heartbeat Time Unit parameter to define the exact interval. Zero or negative value will result in disabling heartbeat requests.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-connection-mode.title: LDAP Connection Mode
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-config-connection-mode.description:
Defines which protocol/operation is used to establish the connection to the LDAP Directory Server.

If 'LDAP' is selected, the connection won't be secured and passwords are transferred in cleartext over the network.
If 'LDAPS' is selected, the connection is secured via SSL or TLS.
If 'StartTLS' is selected, the connection is secured by using StartTLS extended operation.

openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-timeunit.title: LDAP Connection Heartbeat Time Unit
openam-idrepo-ldapv3-heartbeat-timeunit.description:
Defines the time unit corresponding to the Heartbeat Interval setting.

This setting controls how often OpenAM should send a heartbeat search request to the configured directory. If a connection becomes unresponsive (e.g. due to a network error) then it may take up to the interval period before the problem is detected. Use along with the Heartbeat Interval parameter to define the exact interval.

sunIdRepoSupportedOperations.title: LDAPv3 Plug-in Supported Types and Operations

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-size.title: DN Cache Size
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-size.description: In DN items, only used when DN Cache is enabled.

sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-enabled.title: DN Cache
sun-idrepo-ldapv3-dncache-enabled.description:
Used to enable/disable the DN Cache within the OpenAM repository implementation.

The DN Cache is used to cache DN lookups which tend to happen in bursts during authentication. The DN Cache can become out of date when a user is moved or renamed in the underlying LDAP store and this is not reflected in a persistent search result. Enable when the underlying LDAP store supports persistent search and move/rename (mod_dn) results are available.

com.iplanet.services.debug.level.title: Debug Level
com.iplanet.services.debug.level.description: Debug level for all components in the product. (property name: com.iplanet.services.debug.level)

com.sun.services.debug.mergeall.title: Merge Debug Files
com.sun.services.debug.mergeall.description: On : Directs all debug data to a single file (debug.out); Off : creates separate per-component debug files (property name : com.sun.services.debug.mergeall)

1.0.title: Default General Properties
1.0.description: An object of property key-value pairs

actions.description: Obtain the value schema for this resource.
actions.name: schema

openam-session-stateless-enable-session-.title: Enable Session Blacklisting
openam-session-stateless-enable-session-.description:
Blacklists client-based sessions that log out.

We recommend enabling this setting if the maximum session time is high. Blacklist state is stored in the Core Token Service (CTS) token store until the session expires, in order to ensure that sessions cannot continue to be used. Requires a server restart for changes to take effect.

statelessSigningRsaCertAlias.title: Signing RSA/ECDSA Certificate Alias
statelessSigningRsaCertAlias.description:
Specify the alias of a certificate containing a public/private key pair that AM uses when performing RSA or ECDSA signing on the session JWT. Specify a signing certificate alias when using a "Signing Algorithm Type" of RS256, ES256, ES384, or ES512.

The certificate is retrieved from the keystore specified by the com.sun.identity.saml.xmlsig.keystore property.

statelessCompressionType.title: Compression Algorithm
statelessCompressionType.description:
If enabled the session state is compressed before signing and encryption.

WARNING: Enabling compression may compromise encryption. This may leak information about the content of the session state if encryption is enabled.

statelessEncryptionRsaCertAlias.title: Encryption RSA Certificate Alias
statelessEncryptionRsaCertAlias.description:
Specifies the alias of a certificate containing a public/private key pair that AM uses when encrypting a JWT. Specify an encryption certificate alias when using an Encryption Algorithm Type of RSA.

The certificate is retrieved from the keystore referenced by the com.sun.identity.saml.xmlsig.keystore property.

openam-session-stateless-blacklist-poll-.title: Blacklist Poll Interval (seconds)
openam-session-stateless-blacklist-poll-.description:
Specifies the interval at which AM polls the Core Token Service to update the list of logged out sessions, in seconds.

The longer the polling interval, the more time a malicious user has to connect to other AM servers in a deployment and make use of a stolen session cookie. Shortening the polling interval improves the security for logged out sessions, but might incur a minimal decrease in overall AM performance due to increased network activity. Set to 0 to disable this feature completely.

statelessEncryptionAesKey.title: Encryption Symmetric AES Key
statelessEncryptionAesKey.description:
AES key for use with Direct or AES KeyWrap encryption modes.

The symmetric AES key is a base64-encoded random key.

For direct encryption with AES-GCM or for AES-KeyWrap with any content encryption method, this should be 128, 192, or 256 bits.

For direct encryption with AES-CBC-HMAC, the key should be double those sizes (one half for the AES key, the other have for the HMAC key).

AES key sizes greater than 128 bits require installation of the JCE Unlimited Strength policy files in your JRE.

statelessSigningType.title: Signing Algorithm Type
statelessSigningType.description:
Specifies the algorithm that AM uses to sign the JSON Web Token (JWT) containing the session content. Signing the JWT enables tampering detection.

AM supports the following signing algorithms:
  • HS256. HMAC using SHA-256.
  • HS384. HMAC using SHA-384.
  • HS512. HMAC using SHA-512.
  • RS256. RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5 using SHA-256.
  • ES256. ECDSA using SHA-256 and NIST standard P-256 elliptic curve.
  • ES384. ECDSA using SHA-384 and NIST standard P-384 elliptic curve.
  • ES512. ECDSA using SHA-512 and NIST standard P-521 elliptic curve.

statelessEncryptionType.title: Encryption Algorithm
statelessEncryptionType.description:
Specifies the algorithm that AM uses to encrypt the JSON Web Token (JWT) containing the session content.

AM supports the following encryption algorithms:
  • NONE. No encryption is selected.
  • RSA. Session content is encrypted with AES using a unique key. The key is then encrypted with an RSA public key and appended to the JWT.

    AM supports the following padding modes, which you can set using the org.forgerock.openam.session.stateless.rsa.padding advanced property:

    • RSA1_5. RSA with PKCS#1 v1.5 padding.
    • RSA-OAEP. RSA with optimal asymmetric encryption padding (OAEP) and SHA-1.
    • RSA-OAEP-256. RSA with OAEP padding and SHA-256.
  • AES KeyWrapping. Session content is encrypted with AES using a unique key and is then wrapped using AES KeyWrap and the master key. This provides additional security, compared to RSA, at the cost of 128 or 256 bits (or 32 bytes) depending on the size of the master key. This method provides authenticated encryption, which removes the need for a separate signature and decreases the byte size of the JWT. See RFC 3394.
  • Direct AES Encryption. Session content is encrypted with direct AES encryption with a symmetric key. This method provides authenticated encryption, which removes the need for a separate signature and decreases the byte size of the JWT.

Important: To prevent users from accidentally disabling all authentication support, which can be accomplished by disabling signing and not using an authenticated encryption mode, you must set the org.forgerock.openam.session.stateless.signing.allownone system property to true to turn off signing completely.

openam-session-stateless-blacklist-purge.title: Blacklist Purge Delay (minutes)
openam-session-stateless-blacklist-purge.description:
When added to the maximum session time, specifies the amount of time that AM tracks logged out sessions.

Increase the blacklist purge delay if you expect system clock skews in a deployment of AM servers to be greater than one minute. There is no need to increase the blacklist purge delay for servers running a clock synchronization protocol, such as Network Time Protocol.

statelessSigningHmacSecret.title: Signing HMAC Shared Secret
statelessSigningHmacSecret.description:
Specifies the shared secret that AM uses when performing HMAC signing on the session JWT.

Specify a shared secret when using a "Signing Algorithm Type" of HS256, HS384, or HS512.

openam-session-stateless-blacklist-cache.title: Session Blacklist Cache Size
openam-session-stateless-blacklist-cache.description: Number of blacklisted sessions to cache in memory to speed up blacklist checks and reduce load on the CTS. The cache size should be approximately the number of logouts expected in the maximum session time.

latestAccessTimeUpdateFrequency.title: Latest Access Time Update Frequency
latestAccessTimeUpdateFrequency.description:
Defaults to 60 seconds. At most, AM updates a session's latest access time this often.

Subsequent touches to the session that occur within the specified number of seconds after an update will not cause additional updates to the session's access time.

Refreshing a session returns the idle time as the number of seconds since an update has occurred, which will be between 0 and the specified Latest Access Time Update Frequency.

timeoutHandlers.title: Session Timeout Handler implementations
timeoutHandlers.description: Lists plugin classes implementing session timeout handlers. Specify the fully qualified name.

dnRestrictionOnly.title: DN Restriction Only Enabled
dnRestrictionOnly.description: If enabled, OpenAM will not perform DNS lookups when checking restrictions in cookie hijacking mode.

quotaConstraintMaxWaitTime.title: Read Timeout for Quota Constraint
quotaConstraintMaxWaitTime.description: Maximum wait time after which OpenAM considers a search for live session count as having failed if quota constraints are enabled, in milliseconds.

iplanet-am-session-enable-session-constr.title: Enable Quota Constraints
iplanet-am-session-enable-session-constr.description: If on, then OpenAM allows you to set quota constraints on CTS-based sessions.

behaviourWhenQuotaExhausted.title: Resulting behavior if session quota exhausted
behaviourWhenQuotaExhausted.description:
Specify the action to take if a session quota is exhausted:
  • Deny Access. New session creation requests will be denied.
  • Destroy Next Expiring. The session that would expire next will be destroyed.
  • Destroy Oldest. The oldest session will be destroyed.
  • Destroy All. All previous sessions will be destroyed.

denyLoginWhenRepoDown.title: Deny user login when session repository is down
denyLoginWhenRepoDown.description: This property only takes effect when the session quota constraint is enabled, and the session data store is unavailable.

notificationPropertyList.title: Notification Properties
notificationPropertyList.description: Lists session properties for which OpenAM can send notifications upon modification. Session notification applies to CTS-based sessions only.

propertyChangeNotifications.title: Enable Property Change Notifications
propertyChangeNotifications.description: If on, then OpenAM notifies other applications participating in SSO when a session property in the Notification Properties list changes on a CTS-based session.

iplanet-am-session-constraint-resulting-.title: Resulting behavior if session quota exhausted
iplanet-am-session-constraint-resulting-.description:
Specify the action to take if a session quota is exhausted:
  • Deny Access. New session creation requests will be denied.
  • Destroy Next Expiring. The session that would expire next will be destroyed.
  • Destroy Oldest. The oldest session will be destroyed.
  • Destroy All. All previous sessions will be destroyed.

sessionListRetrievalTimeout.title: Timeout for Search
sessionListRetrievalTimeout.description: Time after which OpenAM sees an incomplete search as having failed, in seconds.

maxSessionListSize.title: Maximum Number of Search Results
maxSessionListSize.description: Maximum number of results from a session search. Do not set this attribute to a large value, for example more than 1000, unless sufficient system resources are allocated.

maxIdleTime.title: Maximum Idle Time
maxIdleTime.description: Maximum time a CTS-based session can remain idle before OpenAM requires the user to authenticate again, in minutes.

maxCachingTime.title: Maximum Caching Time
maxCachingTime.description: Maximum time that external clients of AM are recommended to cache the session for, in minutes.

quotaLimit.title: Active User Sessions
quotaLimit.description: Maximum number of concurrent CTS-based sessions OpenAM allows a user to have.

maxSessionTime.title: Maximum Session Time
maxSessionTime.description: Maximum time a session can remain valid before OpenAM requires the user to authenticate again, in minutes.

smsGatewayImplementationClass.description:
The OTP Email Sender node uses this class to send email messages.

The gateway class must implement the following interface:
com.sun.identity.authentication.modules.hotp.SMSGateway

emailAttribute.title: Email Attribute Name
emailAttribute.description: This is the attribute name used by the OTP Sender to email the user

sslOption.description: This setting controls whether the authentication module communicates with the mail server using SSL/TLS.

password.title: Mail Server Authentication Password
password.description: The password to use when the mail server is using SMTP authentication

fromEmailAddress.title: Email From Address
fromEmailAddress.description: Emails from the OTP Email Sender node will come from this address.

hostPort.title: Mail Server Host Port
hostPort.description: The port of the mail server. The default port for SMTP is 25, if using SSL the default port is 465.

username.title: Mail Server Authentication Username
username.description: The username to use when the mail server is using SMTP authentication

hostName.title: Mail Server Host Name
hostName.description: The name of the mail server OpenAM will use to send the messages.

operationTimeout.title: LDAP operations timeout
operationTimeout.description:
Defines the timeout in seconds OpenAM should wait for a response of the Directory Server - 0 means no timeout.

If the Directory Server's host is down completely or the TCP connection became stale OpenAM waits until operation timeouts from the OS or the JVM are applied. However this setting allows more granular control within OpenAM itself. A value of 0 means NO timeout is applied on OpenAM level and the timeouts from the JVM or OS will apply.

minimumPasswordLength.title: Minimum Password Length
minimumPasswordLength.description:
Enforced when the user is resetting their password as part of the authentication.

If the user needs to reset their password as part of the authentication process, the authentication module can enforce a minimum password length. This is separate from any password length controls from the underlying LDAP server. If the external LDAP server password policy is enforcing password length, set this value to 0 to avoid confusion.

userSearchStartDN.title: DN to Start User Search
userSearchStartDN.description:
The search for accounts to be authenticated start from this base DN

For a single server just enter the Base DN to be searched. Multiple OpenAM servers can have different base DNs for the search The format is as follows:

local server name | search DN

NB The local server name is the full name of the server from the list of servers and sites.

beheraPasswordPolicySupportEnabled.title: LDAP Behera Password Policy Support
beheraPasswordPolicySupportEnabled.description:
Enables support for modern LDAP password policies

LDAP Behera Password policies are supported by modern LDAP servers such as OpenDJ. If this functionality is disabled then only the older Netscape VCHU password policy standard will be enforced.

connectionHeartbeatTimeUnit.title: LDAP Connection Heartbeat Time Unit
connectionHeartbeatTimeUnit.description:
Defines the time unit corresponding to the Heartbeat Interval setting.

This setting controls how often OpenAM should send a heartbeat search request to the configured directory. If a connection becomes unresponsive (e.g. due to a network error) then it may take up to the interval period before the problem is detected. Use along with the Heartbeat Interval parameter to define the exact interval.

trustAllServerCertificates.title: Trust All Server Certificates
trustAllServerCertificates.description:
Enables a X509TrustManager that trusts all certificates.

This feature will allow the LDAP authentication module to connect to LDAP servers protected by self signed or invalid certificates (such as invalid hostname).

NB Use this feature with care as it bypasses the normal certificate verification process

connectionHeartbeatInterval.title: LDAP Connection Heartbeat Interval
connectionHeartbeatInterval.description:
Specifies how often should OpenAM send a heartbeat request to the directory.

This setting controls how often OpenAM should send a heartbeat search request to the configured directory. If a connection becomes unresponsive (e.g. due to a network error) then it may take up to the interval period before the problem is detected. Use along with the Heartbeat Time Unit parameter to define the exact interval. Zero or negative value will result in disabling heartbeat requests.

openam-auth-ldap-connection-mode.title: LDAP Connection Mode
openam-auth-ldap-connection-mode.description:
Defines which protocol/operation is used to establish the connection to the LDAP Directory Server.

If 'LDAP' is selected, the connection won't be secured and passwords are transferred in cleartext over the network.
If 'LDAPS' is selected, the connection is secured via SSL or TLS.
If 'StartTLS' is selected, the connection is secured by using StartTLS extended operation.

secondaryLdapServer.title: Secondary LDAP Server
secondaryLdapServer.description:
Use this list to set the secondary (failover) LDAP server used for authentication.

If the primary LDAP server fails, the LDAP authentication module will failover to the secondary server. A single entry must be in the format:

ldap_server:port

Multiple entries allow associations between OpenAM servers and a LDAP server. The format is:

local server name | server:port

NB The local server name is the full name of the server from the list of servers and sites.

userSearchFilter.title: User Search Filter
userSearchFilter.description:
This search filter will be appended to the standard user search filter.

This attribute can be used to append a custom search filter to the standard filter. For example: (objectClass=person)would result in the following user search filter:

(&(uid=user)(objectClass=person))

profileAttributeMappings.title: User Creation Attributes
profileAttributeMappings.description:
Controls the mapping of local attribute to external attribute for dynamic profile creation.

If dynamic profile creation is enabled; this feature allows for a mapping between the attribute/values retrieved from the users authenticated profile and the attribute/values that will be provisioned into their matching account in the data store.

The format of this property is:

local attr1|external attr1

userBindPassword.title: Bind User Password
userBindPassword.description: The password of the administration account.

returnUserDN.title: Return User DN to DataStore
returnUserDN.description: Controls whether the DN or the username is returned as the authentication principal.

userBindDN.title: Bind User DN
userBindDN.description:
The DN of an admin user used by the module to authentication to the LDAP server

The LDAP module requires an administration account in order to perform functionality such as password reset.

NB cn=Directory Manager should not be used in production systems.

searchScope.title: Search Scope
searchScope.description:
The level in the Directory Server that will be searched for a matching user profile.

This attribute controls how the directory is searched.

  • OBJECT: Only the Base DN is searched.
  • ONELEVEL: Only the single level below (and not the Base DN) is searched
  • SUBTREE: The Base DN and all levels below are searched

primaryLdapServer.title: Primary LDAP Server
primaryLdapServer.description:
Use this list to set the primary LDAP server used for authentication.

The LDAP authentication module will use this list as the primary server for authentication. A single entry must be in the format:

ldap_server:port

Multiple entries allow associations between OpenAM servers and a LDAP server. The format is:

local server name | server:port

The local server name is the full name of the server from the list of servers and sites.

userSearchAttributes.title: Attributes Used to Search for a User to be Authenticated
userSearchAttributes.description:
The attributes specified in this list form the LDAP search filter.

The default value of uid will form the following search filter of uid=user, if there are multiple values such as uid and cn, the module will create a search filter as follows (|(uid=user)(cn=user))

userProfileRetrievalAttribute.title: Attribute Used to Retrieve User Profile
userProfileRetrievalAttribute.description:
The LDAP module will use this attribute to search of the profile of an authenticated user.

This is the attribute used to find the profile of the authenticated user. Normally this will be the same attribute used to find the user account. The value will be the name of the user used for authentication.

authenticationLevel.title: Authentication Level
authenticationLevel.description:
The authentication level associated with this module.

Each authentication module has an authentication level that can be used to indicate the level of security associated with the module; 0 is the lowest (and the default).
