blacklistCacheSize.title: Token Blacklist Cache Size
blacklistCacheSize.description: Number of blacklisted tokens to cache in memory to speed up blacklist checks and reduce load on the CTS.

storageScheme.title: CTS Storage Scheme
storageScheme.description:
Storage scheme to be used when storing OAuth2 tokens to CTS.

In order to support rolling upgrades, this should be set to the latest storage scheme supported by all OpenAM instances within your cluster. Select the latest storage scheme once all OpenAM instances in the cluster have been upgraded.

One-to-One Storage Scheme
Under this storage scheme, each OAuth2 token maps to an individual CTS entry.
This storage scheme is deprecated.

Grant-Set Storage Scheme
Under this storage scheme, multiple authorization code, access token and refresh token for a given OAuth2 client and resource owner can be stored within a single CTS entry.
The Grant-Set storage scheme is more efficient than the One-to-One storage scheme so should be used once all servers have been upgraded to a version which supports this storage scheme

statelessGrantTokenUpgradeCompatibilityM.title: Client-Based Grant Token Upgrade Compatibility Mode
statelessGrantTokenUpgradeCompatibilityM.description:
Enable OpenAM to consume and create client-based OAuth 2.0 tokens in two different formats simultaneously.

Enable this option when upgrading OpenAM to allow the new instance to create and consume client-based OAuth 2.0 tokens in both the previous format, and the new format. Disable this option once all OpenAM instances in the cluster have been upgraded.

blacklistPollInterval.title: Blacklist Poll Interval (seconds)
blacklistPollInterval.description:
How frequently to poll for token blacklist changes from other servers, in seconds.

How often each server will poll the CTS for token blacklist changes from other servers. This is used to maintain a highly compressed view of the overall current token blacklist improving performance. A lower number will reduce the delay for blacklisted tokens to propagate to all servers at the cost of increased CTS load. Set to 0 to disable this feature completely.

blacklistPurgeDelay.title: Blacklist Purge Delay (minutes)
blacklistPurgeDelay.description:
Length of time to blacklist tokens beyond their expiry time.

Allows additional time to account for clock skew to ensure that a token has expired before it is removed from the blacklist.

jwtTokenUnreasonableLifetime.title: JWT Unreasonable Lifetime (seconds)
jwtTokenUnreasonableLifetime.description:
Specify the lifetime (in seconds) of a JWT which should be considered unreasonable and rejected by validation.

The JSON Web Token (JWT) Profile for OAuth 2.0 Client Authentication and Authorization Grants specification (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7523#section-3) states that an authorization server may reject JWTs with an "exp" claim value that is unreasonably far in the future and an "iat" claim value that is unreasonably far in the past. During token validation AM enforces that the token must expire within the specified duration and if the "iat" claim value is present, the token must not be older than the specified duration.

jwtTokenLifetimeValidationEnabled.title: Enforce JWT Unreasonable Lifetime
jwtTokenLifetimeValidationEnabled.description:
Enable the enforcement of JWT token unreasonable lifetime during validation.

The JSON Web Token (JWT) Profile for OAuth 2.0 Client Authentication and Authorization Grants specification (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7523#section-3) states that an authorization server may reject JWTs with an "exp" claim value that is unreasonably far in the future and an "iat" claim value that is unreasonably far in the past. This enforcement may be disabled, but should only be done if the security implications have been evaluated.

jkwsURI.title: Remote JSON Web Key URL
jkwsURI.description:
The Remote URL where the providers JSON Web Key can be retrieved.

If this setting is not configured, then OpenAM provides a local URL to access the public key of the private key used to sign ID tokens.

claimsParameterSupported.title: Enable "claims_parameter_supported"
claimsParameterSupported.description: If enabled, clients will be able to request individual claims using the claims request parameter, as per section 5.5 of the OpenID Connect specification.

idTokenInfoClientAuthenticationEnabled.title: Idtokeninfo Endpoint Requires Client Authentication
idTokenInfoClientAuthenticationEnabled.description: When enabled, the /oauth2/idtokeninfo endpoint requires client authentication if the signing algorithm is set to HS256, HS384, or HS512.

supportedRequestParameterSigningAlgorith.title: Request Parameter Signing Algorithms Supported
supportedRequestParameterSigningAlgorith.description:
Algorithms supported to verify signature of Request parameterOpenAM supports signing algorithms listed in JSON Web Algorithms (JWA): "alg" (Algorithm) Header Parameter Values for JWS:
  • HS256 - HMAC with SHA-256.
  • HS384 - HMAC with SHA-384.
  • HS512 - HMAC with SHA-512.
  • ES256 - ECDSA with SHA-256 and NIST standard P-256 elliptic curve.
  • ES384 - ECDSA with SHA-384 and NIST standard P-384 elliptic curve.
  • ES512 - ECDSA with SHA-512 and NIST standard P-521 elliptic curve.
  • RS256 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.

supportedUserInfoEncryptionEnc.title: UserInfo Encryption Methods Supported
supportedUserInfoEncryptionEnc.description:
Encryption methods supported by the UserInfo endpoint.

OpenAM supports the following UserInfo endpoint encryption methods:
  • A128GCM, A192GCM, and A256GCM - AES in Galois Counter Mode (GCM) authenticated encryption mode.
  • A128CBC-HS256, A192CBC-HS384, and A256CBC-HS512 - AES encryption in CBC mode, with HMAC-SHA-2 for integrity.

supportedUserInfoSigningAlgorithms.title: UserInfo Signing Algorithms Supported
supportedUserInfoSigningAlgorithms.description:
Algorithms supported to verify signature of the UserInfo endpoint. OpenAM supports signing algorithms listed in JSON Web Algorithms (JWA): "alg" (Algorithm) Header Parameter Values for JWS:
  • HS256 - HMAC with SHA-256.
  • HS384 - HMAC with SHA-384.
  • HS512 - HMAC with SHA-512.
  • ES256 - ECDSA with SHA-256 and NIST standard P-256 elliptic curve.
  • ES384 - ECDSA with SHA-384 and NIST standard P-384 elliptic curve.
  • ES512 - ECDSA with SHA-512 and NIST standard P-521 elliptic curve.
  • RS256 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.

storeOpsTokens.title: Store Ops Tokens
storeOpsTokens.description: Whether OpenAM will store the ops tokens corresponding to OpenID Connect sessions in the CTS store. Note that session management related endpoints will not work when this setting is disabled.

supportedTokenEndpointAuthenticationSign.title: Supported Token Endpoint JWS Signing Algorithms.
supportedTokenEndpointAuthenticationSign.description: Supported JWS Signing Algorithms for 'private_key_jwt' JWT based authentication method.

authorisedOpenIdConnectSSOClients.title: Authorized OIDC SSO Clients
authorisedOpenIdConnectSSOClients.description:
Clients authorized to use OpenID Connect ID tokens as SSO Tokens.

Allows clients to act with the full authority of the user. Grant this permission only to trusted clients.

supportedUserInfoEncryptionAlgorithms.title: UserInfo Encryption Algorithms Supported
supportedUserInfoEncryptionAlgorithms.description:
Encryption algorithms supported by the UserInfo endpoint.

OpenAM supports the following UserInfo endpoint encryption algorithms:
  • RSA-OAEP - RSA with Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) with SHA-1 and MGF-1.
  • RSA-OAEP-256 - RSA with OAEP with SHA-256 and MGF-1.
  • A128KW - AES Key Wrapping with 128-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • RSA1_5 - RSA with PKCS#1 v1.5 padding.
  • A256KW - AES Key Wrapping with 256-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • dir - Direct encryption with AES using the hashed client secret.
  • A192KW - AES Key Wrapping with 192-bit key derived from the client secret.

supportedRequestParameterEncryptionEnc.title: Request Parameter Encryption Methods Supported
supportedRequestParameterEncryptionEnc.description:
Encryption methods supported to decrypt Request parameter.

OpenAM supports the following Request parameter encryption algorithms:
  • A128GCM, A192GCM, and A256GCM - AES in Galois Counter Mode (GCM) authenticated encryption mode.
  • A128CBC-HS256, A192CBC-HS384, and A256CBC-HS512 - AES encryption in CBC mode, with HMAC-SHA-2 for integrity.

amrMappings.title: OpenID Connect id_token amr Values to Auth Module Mappings
amrMappings.description: Specify amr values to be returned in the OpenID Connect id_token. Once authentication has completed, the authentication modules that were used from the authentication service will be mapped to the amr values. If you do not require amr values, or are not providing OpenID Connect tokens, leave this field blank.

alwaysAddClaimsToToken.title: Always Return Claims in ID Tokens
alwaysAddClaimsToToken.description:
If enabled, include scope-derived claims in the id_token, even if an access token is also returned that could provide access to get the claims from the userinfo endpoint.

If not enabled, if an access token is requested the client must use it to access the userinfo endpoint for scope-derived claims, as they will not be included in the ID token.

loaMapping.title: OpenID Connect acr_values to Auth Chain Mapping
loaMapping.description: Maps OpenID Connect ACR values to authentication chains. For more details, see the acr_values parameter in the OpenID Connect authentication request specification.

supportedRequestParameterEncryptionAlgor.title: Request Parameter Encryption Algorithms Supported
supportedRequestParameterEncryptionAlgor.description:
Encryption algorithms supported to decrypt Request parameter.

OpenAM supports the following ID token encryption algorithms:
  • RSA-OAEP - RSA with Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) with SHA-1 and MGF-1.
  • RSA-OAEP-256 - RSA with OAEP with SHA-256 and MGF-1.
  • A128KW - AES Key Wrapping with 128-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • RSA1_5 - RSA with PKCS#1 v1.5 padding.
  • A256KW - AES Key Wrapping with 256-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • dir - Direct encryption with AES using the hashed client secret.
  • A192KW - AES Key Wrapping with 192-bit key derived from the client secret.

defaultACR.title: Default ACR values
defaultACR.description:
Default requested Authentication Context Class Reference values.

List of strings that specifies the default acr values that the OP is being requested to use for processing requests from this Client, with the values appearing in order of preference. The Authentication Context Class satisfied by the authentication performed is returned as the acr Claim Value in the issued ID Token. The acr Claim is requested as a Voluntary Claim by this parameter. The acr_values_supported discovery element contains a list of the acr values supported by this server. Values specified in the acr_values request parameter or an individual acr Claim request override these default values.

statelessTokensEnabled.title: Use Client-Based Access & Refresh Tokens
statelessTokensEnabled.description: When enabled, OpenAM issues access and refresh tokens that can be inspected by resource servers.

usePolicyEngineForScope.title: Use Policy Engine for Scope decisions
usePolicyEngineForScope.description:
With this setting enabled, the policy engine is consulted for each scope value that is requested.

If a policy returns an action of GRANT=true, the scope is consented automatically, and the user is not consulted in a user-interaction flow. If a policy returns an action of GRANT=false, the scope is not added to any resulting token, and the user will not see it in a user-interaction flow. If no policy returns a value for the GRANT action, then if the grant type is user-facing (i.e. authorization or device code flows), the user is asked for consent (or saved consent is used), and if the grant type is not user-facing (password or client credentials), the scope is not added to any resulting token.

accessTokenModificationScript.title: OAuth2 Access Token Modification Script
accessTokenModificationScript.description: The script that is executed when issuing an access token. The script can change the access token's internal data structure to include or exclude particular fields.

refreshTokenLifetime.title: Refresh Token Lifetime (seconds)
refreshTokenLifetime.description: The time in seconds a refresh token is valid for. If this field is set to -1, the token will never expire.

accessTokenLifetime.title: Access Token Lifetime (seconds)
accessTokenLifetime.description: The time an access token is valid for, in seconds. When set to -1, the token will never expire. When set to 0, the token will not be valid. A maximum lifetime of 600 seconds is recommended.

issueRefreshToken.title: Issue Refresh Tokens
issueRefreshToken.description: Whether to issue a refresh token when returning an access token.

issueRefreshTokenOnRefreshedToken.title: Issue Refresh Tokens on Refreshing Access Tokens
issueRefreshTokenOnRefreshedToken.description: Whether to issue a refresh token when refreshing an access token.

codeLifetime.title: Authorization Code Lifetime (seconds)
codeLifetime.description: The time an authorization code is valid for, in seconds.

tokenCompressionEnabled.title: Client-Based Token Compression
tokenCompressionEnabled.description: Whether client-based access and refresh tokens should be compressed.

supportedSubjectTypes.title: Subject Types supported
supportedSubjectTypes.description:
List of subject types supported. Valid values are:
  • public - Each client receives the same subject (sub) value.
  • pairwise - Each client receives a different subject (sub) value, to prevent correlation between clients.

defaultScopes.title: Default Client Scopes
defaultScopes.description: List of scopes a client will be granted if they request registration without specifying which scopes they want. Default scopes are NOT auto-granted to clients created through the OpenAM console.

tlsClientCertificateTrustedHeader.title: Trusted TLS Client Certificate Header
tlsClientCertificateTrustedHeader.description:
HTTP Header to receive TLS client certificates when TLS is terminated at a proxy.

Leave blank if not terminating TLS at a proxy. Ensure that the proxy is configured to strip this headerfrom incoming requests. Best practice is to use a random string.

moduleMessageEnabledInPasswordGrant.title: Enable Auth Module Messages for Password Credentials Grant
moduleMessageEnabledInPasswordGrant.description:
If enabled, authentication module failure messages are used to create Resource Owner Password Credentials Grant failure messages. If disabled, a standard authentication failed message is used.

The Password Grant Type requires the grant_type=password parameter.

supportedScopes.title: Supported Scopes
supportedScopes.description:
The set of supported scopes, with translations.

Scopes may be entered as simple strings or pipe-separated strings representing the internal scope name, locale, and localized description.

For example: read|en|Permission to view email messages in your account

Locale strings are in the format: language_country_variant, for example en, en_GB, or en_US_WIN.

If the locale and pipe is omitted, the description is displayed to all users that have undefined locales.

If the description is also omitted, nothing is displayed on the consent page for the scope. For example specifying read| would allow the scope read to be used by the client, but would not display it to the user on the consent page when requested.

tokenSigningAlgorithm.title: OAuth2 Token Signing Algorithm
tokenSigningAlgorithm.description:
Algorithm used to sign client-based OAuth 2.0 tokens in order to detect tampering.

OpenAM supports signing algorithms listed in JSON Web Algorithms (JWA): "alg" (Algorithm) Header Parameter Values for JWS:
  • HS256 - HMAC with SHA-256.
  • HS384 - HMAC with SHA-384.
  • HS512 - HMAC with SHA-512.
  • ES256 - ECDSA with SHA-256 and NIST standard P-256 elliptic curve.
  • ES384 - ECDSA with SHA-384 and NIST standard P-384 elliptic curve.
  • ES512 - ECDSA with SHA-512 and NIST standard P-521 elliptic curve.
  • RS256 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.

passwordGrantAuthService.title: Password Grant Authentication Service
passwordGrantAuthService.description: The authentication service (chain or tree) that will be used to authenticate the username and password for the resource owner password credentials grant type.

tokenEncryptionEnabled.title: Encrypt Client-Based Tokens
tokenEncryptionEnabled.description:
Whether client-based access and refresh tokens should be encrypted.

Enabling token encryption will disable token signing as encryption is performed using direct symmetric encryption.

createdTimestampAttribute.title: Created Timestamp Attribute Name
createdTimestampAttribute.description: The identity Data Store attribute used to return created timestamp values.

hashSalt.title: Subject Identifier Hash Salt
hashSalt.description: If pairwise subject types are supported, it is STRONGLY RECOMMENDED to change this value. It is used in the salting of hashes for returning specific sub claims to individuals using the same request_uri or sector_identifier_uri.

displayNameAttribute.title: User Display Name attribute
displayNameAttribute.description: The profile attribute that contains the name to be displayed for the user on the consent page.

responseTypeClasses.title: Response Type Plugins
responseTypeClasses.description:
List of plugins that handle the valid response_type values.

OAuth 2.0 clients pass response types as parameters to the OAuth 2.0 Authorization endpoint (/oauth2/authorize) to indicate which grant type is requested from the provider. For example, the client passes code when requesting an authorization code, and token when requesting an access token.

Values in this list take the form response-type|plugin-class-name.

scopeImplementationClass.title: Scope Implementation Class
scopeImplementationClass.description: The class that contains the required scope implementation, must implement the org.forgerock.oauth2.core.ScopeValidator interface.

codeVerifierEnforced.title: Code Verifier Parameter Required
codeVerifierEnforced.description:
If enabled, requests using the authorization code grant require a code_challenge attribute.

For more information, read the specification for this feature.

customLoginUrlTemplate.title: Custom Login URL Template
customLoginUrlTemplate.description:
Custom URL for handling login, to override the default OpenAM login page.

Supports Freemarker syntax, with the following variables:
VariableDescription
gotoUrl

The URL to redirect to after login.

acrValues

The Authentication Context Class Reference (acr) values for the authorization request.

realm

The OpenAM realm the authorization request was made on.

module

The name of the OpenAM authentication module requested to perform resource owner authentication.

service

The name of the OpenAM authentication chain requested to perform resource owner authentication.

locale

A space-separated list of locales, ordered by preference.

The following example template redirects users to a non-OpenAM front end to handle login, which will then redirect back to the /oauth2/authorize endpoint with any required parameters:

http://mylogin.com/login?goto=${goto}<#if acrValues??>&acr_values=${acrValues}</#if><#if realm??>&realm=${realm}</#if><#if module??>&module=${module}</#if><#if service??>&service=${service}</#if><#if locale??>&locale=${locale}</#if>
NOTE: Default OpenAM login page is constructed using "Base URL Source" service.

modifiedTimestampAttribute.title: Modified Timestamp Attribute Name
modifiedTimestampAttribute.description:
The identity Data Store attribute used to return modified timestamp values.

This attribute is paired together with the Created Timestamp Attribute Name attribute (createdTimestampAttribute). You can leave both attributes unset (default) or set them both. If you set only one attribute and leave the other blank, the access token fails with a 500 error.

For example, when you configure AM as an OpenID Connect Provider in a Mobile Connect application and use DS as an identity data store, the client accesses the userinfo endpoint to obtain the updated_at claim value in the ID token. The updated_at claim obtains its value from the modifiedTimestampAttribute attribute in the user profile. If the profile has never been modified the updated_at claim uses the createdTimestampAttribute attribute.

tlsCertificateBoundAccessTokensEnabled.title: Support TLS Certificate-Bound Access Tokens
tlsCertificateBoundAccessTokensEnabled.description: Whether to bind access tokens to the client certificate when using TLS client certificate authentication.

authenticationAttributes.title: User Profile Attribute(s) the Resource Owner is Authenticated On
authenticationAttributes.description: Names of profile attributes that resource owners use to log in. You can add others to the default, for example mail.

grantTypes.title: Grant Types
grantTypes.description:
The set of Grant Types (OAuth2 Flows) that are permitted to be used by this client.

If no Grant Types (OAuth2 Flows) are configured nothing will be permitted.

supportedIDTokenEncryptionAlgorithms.title: ID Token Encryption Algorithms supported
supportedIDTokenEncryptionAlgorithms.description:
Encryption algorithms supported to encrypt OpenID Connect ID tokens in order to hide its contents.

OpenAM supports the following ID token encryption algorithms:
  • RSA-OAEP - RSA with Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) with SHA-1 and MGF-1.
  • RSA-OAEP-256 - RSA with OAEP with SHA-256 and MGF-1.
  • A128KW - AES Key Wrapping with 128-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • RSA1_5 - RSA with PKCS#1 v1.5 padding.
  • A256KW - AES Key Wrapping with 256-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • dir - Direct encryption with AES using the hashed client secret.
  • A192KW - AES Key Wrapping with 192-bit key derived from the client secret.

supportedIDTokenEncryptionMethods.title: ID Token Encryption Methods supported
supportedIDTokenEncryptionMethods.description:
Encryption methods supported to encrypt OpenID Connect ID tokens in order to hide its contents.

OpenAM supports the following ID token encryption algorithms:
  • A128GCM, A192GCM, and A256GCM - AES in Galois Counter Mode (GCM) authenticated encryption mode.
  • A128CBC-HS256, A192CBC-HS384, and A256CBC-HS512 - AES encryption in CBC mode, with HMAC-SHA-2 for integrity.

supportedIDTokenSigningAlgorithms.title: ID Token Signing Algorithms supported
supportedIDTokenSigningAlgorithms.description:
Algorithms supported to sign OpenID Connect id_tokens.

OpenAM supports signing algorithms listed in JSON Web Algorithms (JWA): "alg" (Algorithm) Header Parameter Values for JWS:

  • HS256 - HMAC with SHA-256.
  • HS384 - HMAC with SHA-384.
  • HS512 - HMAC with SHA-512.
  • ES256 - ECDSA with SHA-256 and NIST standard P-256 elliptic curve.
  • ES384 - ECDSA with SHA-384 and NIST standard P-384 elliptic curve.
  • ES512 - ECDSA with SHA-512 and NIST standard P-521 elliptic curve.
  • RS256 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.
  • RS384 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-384.
  • RS512 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-512.
  • PS256 - RSASSA-PSS using SHA-256.
  • PS384 - RSASSA-PSS using SHA-384.
  • PS512 - RSASSA-PSS using SHA-512.

supportedClaims.title: Supported Claims
supportedClaims.description:
Set of claims supported by the OpenID Connect /oauth2/userinfo endpoint, with translations.

Claims may be entered as simple strings or pipe separated strings representing the internal claim name, locale, and localized description.

For example: name|en|Your full name..

Locale strings are in the format: language + "_" + country + "_" + variant, for example en, en_GB, or en_US_WIN. If the locale and pipe is omitted, the description is displayed to all users that have undefined locales.

If the description is also omitted, nothing is displayed on the consent page for the claim. For example specifying family_name| would allow the claim family_name to be used by the client, but would not display it to the user on the consent page when requested.

oidcClaimsScript.title: OIDC Claims Script
oidcClaimsScript.description:
The script that is run when issuing an ID token or making a request to the userinfo endpoint during OpenID requests.

The script gathers the scopes and populates claims, and has access to the access token, the user's identity and, if available, the user's session.

jwtTokenLifetime.title: OpenID Connect JWT Token Lifetime (seconds)
jwtTokenLifetime.description: The amount of time the JWT will be valid for, in seconds.

generateRegistrationAccessTokens.title: Generate Registration Access Tokens
generateRegistrationAccessTokens.description: Whether to generate Registration Access Tokens for clients that register by using open dynamic client registration. Such tokens allow the client to access the Client Configuration Endpoint as per the OpenID Connect specification. This setting has no effect if Allow Open Dynamic Client Registration is disabled.

requiredSoftwareStatementAttestedAttribu.title: Required Software Statement Attested Attributes
requiredSoftwareStatementAttestedAttribu.description:
The client attributes that are required to be present in the software statement JWT when registering an OAuth 2.0 client dynamically. Only applies if Require Software Statements for Dynamic Client Registration is enabled.

Leave blank to allow any attributes to be present.

allowDynamicRegistration.title: Allow Open Dynamic Client Registration
allowDynamicRegistration.description: Allow clients to register without an access token. If enabled, you should consider adding some form of rate limiting. For more information, see Client Registration in the OpenID Connect specification.

dynamicClientRegistrationScope.title: Scope to give access to dynamic client registration
dynamicClientRegistrationScope.description: Mandatory scope required when registering a new OAuth2 client.

dynamicClientRegistrationSoftwareStateme.title: Require Software Statement for Dynamic Client Registration
dynamicClientRegistrationSoftwareStateme.description: When enabled, a software statement JWT containing at least the iss (issuer) claim must be provided when registering an OAuth 2.0 client dynamically.

supportedRcsRequestEncryptionMethods.title: Remote Consent Service Request Encryption Methods Supported
supportedRcsRequestEncryptionMethods.description:
Encryption methods supported to encrypt Remote Consent Service requests.

OpenAM supports the following encryption methods:
  • A128GCM, A192GCM, and A256GCM - AES in Galois Counter Mode (GCM) authenticated encryption mode.
  • A128CBC-HS256, A192CBC-HS384, and A256CBC-HS512 - AES encryption in CBC mode, with HMAC-SHA-2 for integrity.

savedConsentAttribute.title: Saved Consent Attribute Name
savedConsentAttribute.description:
Name of a multi-valued attribute on resource owner profiles where OpenAM can save authorization consent decisions.

When the resource owner chooses to save the decision to authorize access for a client application, then OpenAM updates the resource owner's profile to avoid having to prompt the resource owner to grant authorization when the client issues subsequent authorization requests.

clientsCanSkipConsent.title: Allow Clients to Skip Consent
clientsCanSkipConsent.description: If enabled, clients may be configured so that the resource owner will not be asked for consent during authorization flows.

supportedRcsResponseEncryptionMethods.title: Remote Consent Service Response Encryption Methods Supported
supportedRcsResponseEncryptionMethods.description:
Encryption methods supported to decrypt Remote Consent Service responses.

OpenAM supports the following encryption methods:
  • A128GCM, A192GCM, and A256GCM - AES in Galois Counter Mode (GCM) authenticated encryption mode.
  • A128CBC-HS256, A192CBC-HS384, and A256CBC-HS512 - AES encryption in CBC mode, with HMAC-SHA-2 for integrity.

supportedRcsRequestSigningAlgorithms.title: Remote Consent Service Request Signing Algorithms Supported
supportedRcsRequestSigningAlgorithms.description:
Algorithms supported to sign consent_request JWTs for Remote Consent Services.

OpenAM supports signing algorithms listed in JSON Web Algorithms (JWA): "alg" (Algorithm) Header Parameter Values for JWS:
  • HS256 - HMAC with SHA-256.
  • HS384 - HMAC with SHA-384.
  • HS512 - HMAC with SHA-512.
  • ES256 - ECDSA with SHA-256 and NIST standard P-256 elliptic curve.
  • ES384 - ECDSA with SHA-384 and NIST standard P-384 elliptic curve.
  • ES512 - ECDSA with SHA-512 and NIST standard P-521 elliptic curve.
  • RS256 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.

remoteConsentServiceId.title: Remote Consent Service ID
remoteConsentServiceId.description: The ID of an existing remote consent service agent.

supportedRcsRequestEncryptionAlgorithms.title: Remote Consent Service Request Encryption Algorithms Supported
supportedRcsRequestEncryptionAlgorithms.description:
Encryption algorithms supported to encrypt Remote Consent Service requests.

OpenAM supports the following encryption algorithms:
  • RSA1_5 - RSA with PKCS#1 v1.5 padding.
  • RSA-OAEP - RSA with Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) with SHA-1 and MGF-1.
  • RSA-OAEP-256 - RSA with OAEP with SHA-256 and MGF-1.
  • A128KW - AES Key Wrapping with 128-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • A192KW - AES Key Wrapping with 192-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • A256KW - AES Key Wrapping with 256-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • dir - Direct encryption with AES using the hashed client secret.

supportedRcsResponseEncryptionAlgorithms.title: Remote Consent Service Response Encryption Algorithms Supported
supportedRcsResponseEncryptionAlgorithms.description:
Encryption algorithms supported to decrypt Remote Consent Service responses.

OpenAM supports the following encryption algorithms:
  • RSA1_5 - RSA with PKCS#1 v1.5 padding.
  • RSA-OAEP - RSA with Optimal Asymmetric Encryption Padding (OAEP) with SHA-1 and MGF-1.
  • RSA-OAEP-256 - RSA with OAEP with SHA-256 and MGF-1.
  • A128KW - AES Key Wrapping with 128-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • A192KW - AES Key Wrapping with 192-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • A256KW - AES Key Wrapping with 256-bit key derived from the client secret.
  • dir - Direct encryption with AES using the hashed client secret.

supportedRcsResponseSigningAlgorithms.title: Remote Consent Service Response Signing Algorithms Supported
supportedRcsResponseSigningAlgorithms.description:
Algorithms supported to verify signed consent_response JWT from Remote Consent Services.

OpenAM supports signing algorithms listed in JSON Web Algorithms (JWA): "alg" (Algorithm) Header Parameter Values for JWS:
  • HS256 - HMAC with SHA-256.
  • HS384 - HMAC with SHA-384.
  • HS512 - HMAC with SHA-512.
  • ES256 - ECDSA with SHA-256 and NIST standard P-256 elliptic curve.
  • ES384 - ECDSA with SHA-384 and NIST standard P-384 elliptic curve.
  • ES512 - ECDSA with SHA-512 and NIST standard P-521 elliptic curve.
  • RS256 - RSASSA-PKCS-v1_5 using SHA-256.

cibaMinimumPollingInterval.title: Polling Wait Interval (seconds)
cibaMinimumPollingInterval.description: The minimum amount of time in seconds that the Client should wait between polling requests to the token endpoint

supportedCibaSigningAlgorithms.title: Signing Algorithms Supported
supportedCibaSigningAlgorithms.description:
Algorithms supported to sign the CIBA request parameter.

OpenAM supports signing algorithms listed in JSON Web Algorithms (JWA): "alg" (Algorithm) Header Parameter Values for JWS:

  • ES256 - ECDSA with SHA-256 and NIST standard P-256 elliptic curve.
  • PS256 - RSASSA-PSS using SHA-256.

cibaAuthReqIdLifetime.title: Back Channel Authentication ID Lifetime (seconds)
cibaAuthReqIdLifetime.description: The time back channel authentication request id is valid for, in seconds.

devicePollInterval.title: Device Polling Interval
devicePollInterval.description: The polling frequency for devices waiting for tokens when using the device code flow.

completionUrl.title: Device Completion URL
completionUrl.description: The URL that the user will be sent to on completion of their OAuth 2.0 login and consent when using the device code flow.

verificationUrl.title: Verification URL
verificationUrl.description: The URL that the user will be instructed to visit to complete their OAuth 2.0 login and consent when using the device code flow.

deviceCodeLifetime.title: Device Code Lifetime (seconds)
deviceCodeLifetime.description: The lifetime of the device code, in seconds.

_id.title: ID
_id.description: The identifier of the item within its type

additionalProperties.title: Other properties
additionalProperties.description: Any additional properties for the item (varies based on the schema of the type)

tokenEndpoint.title: Access Token Endpoint URL
tokenEndpoint.description:
OAuth access token endpoint URL

This is the URL endpoint for access token retrieval provided by the OAuth Identity Provider. Refer to the RFC 6749, section 3.2

ssoProxyUrl.title: Proxy URL
ssoProxyUrl.description:
The URL to the OpenAM OAuth proxy JSP

This URL should only be changed from the default, if an external server is performing the GET to POST proxying. The default is /openam/oauth2c/OAuthProxy.jsp

provider.title: Social Provider
provider.description: Social Provider for which this module is being setup.

authorizeEndpoint.title: Authentication Endpoint URL
authorizeEndpoint.description:
OAuth authentication endpoint URL

This is the URL endpoint for OAuth authentication provided by the OAuth Identity Provider

scope.title: Scope
scope.description:
OAuth scope; list of user profile properties

According to the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework, scope is a space-separated list of user profile attributes that the client application requires. The list depends on the permissions that the resource owner grants to the client application.

Some authorization servers use non-standard separators for scopes. For example, Facebook takes a comma-separated list.

subjectProperty.title: Subject Property
subjectProperty.description: Property used to identify which attribute an auth server identifies a user by.

usesBasicAuth.title: Use Basic Auth
usesBasicAuth.description: When enabled, the client will use basic auth for authenticating with  the social auth provider. Enabled by default.

authenticationLevel.title: Authentication Level
authenticationLevel.description:
The authentication level associated with this module.

Each authentication module has an authentication level that can be used to indicate the level of security associated with the module; 0 is the lowest (and the default).

scopeDelimiter.title: Scope Delimiter
scopeDelimiter.description: Delimiter used to separate scope values. Default value is space.

userInfoEndpoint.title: User Profile Service URL
userInfoEndpoint.description:
User profile information URL

This URL endpoint provides user profile information and is provided by the OAuth Identity Provider

NB This URL should return JSON objects in response

clientSecret.title: Client Secret
clientSecret.description:
OAuth client_secret parameter

For more information on the OAuth client_secret parameter refer to the RFC 6749, section 2.3.1

clientId.title: Client Id
clientId.description:
OAuth client_id parameter

For more information on the OAuth client_id parameter refer to the RFC 6749, section 2.3.1

saveAttributesInSession.title: Save attributes in the session
saveAttributesInSession.description: If this option is enabled, the attributes configured in the attribute mapper will be saved into the OpenAM session

enableRegistrationService.title: Use IDM as Registration Service
enableRegistrationService.description:
Whether to use IDM as an external Registration Service to complete registration for new users.

IDM is called and passed these parameters:

  • clientToken: Signed, encrypted JWT of the OAuth 2.0 authentication state.
  • returnParams: Encoded URL parameters, required to be returned to AM to resume authentication after registration in IDM is complete.

attributeMappingClasses.title: Attribute Mapper
attributeMappingClasses.description:
Name of the class that implements the attribute mapping

This class maps the OAuth properties into OpenAM properties. A custom attribute mapper can be provided.

A custom attribute mapper must implement the org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.AttributeMapper interface.
Provided implementations are:
  • org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.JsonAttributeMapper
  • org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.oidc.JwtAttributeMapper (can only be used when using the openid scope)
String constructor parameters can be provided by appending | separated values.

accountProviderClass.title: Account Provider
accountProviderClass.description:
Name of the class implementing the account provider.

This class is used by the module to find the account from the attributes mapped by the Account Mapper org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.AccountProvider interface.
String constructor parameters can be provided by appending | separated values.

accountMapperClass.title: Account Mapper
accountMapperClass.description:
Name of the class implementing the attribute mapping for the account search.

This class is used by the module to map from the account information received from the OAuth Identity Provider into OpenAM.

The class must implement the org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.AttributeMapper interface.
Provided implementations are:
  • org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.JsonAttributeMapper
  • org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.oidc.JwtAttributeMapper (can only be used when using the openid scope)
String constructor parameters can be provided by appending | separated values.

attributeMapperConfiguration.title: Attribute Mapper Configuration
attributeMapperConfiguration.description:
Mapping of OAuth attributes to local OpenAM attributes

Attribute configuration that will be used to map the user info obtained from the OAuth 2.0 Provider to the local user data store in the OpenAM.

Example: OAuth2.0_attribute=local_attribute

anonymousUserName.title: Anonymous User
anonymousUserName.description:
Username of the OpenAM anonymous user

The username of the user that will represent the anonymous user. This user account must already exist in the realm.

createAccount.title: Create account if it does not exist
createAccount.description:
If the OAuth2 account does not exist in the local OpenAM data store, an account will be created dynamically.

If this is enabled, the account mapper could create the account dynamically if there is no account mapped. Before creating the account, a dialog prompting for a password and asking for an activation code can be shown if the parameter "Prompt for password setting and activation code" is enabled.

If this flag is not enabled, 3 alternative options exist:

  1. The accounts need to have a user profile in the OpenAM User Data Store
  2. The user does not have a user profile and the "Ignore Profile" is set in the Authentication Service of the realm.
  3. The account is mapped to an anonymous account (see parameter "Map to anonymous user" and "Anonymous User")

mapToAnonymousUser.title: Map to anonymous user
mapToAnonymousUser.description:
Enabled anonymous user access to OpenAM for OAuth authenticated users

If selected, the authenticated users in the OAuth 2.0 Provider will be mapped to the anonymous user configured in the next parameter.
If not selected the users authenticated will be mapped by the parameters configured in the account mapper.

NB If Create account if it does not exist is enabled, that parameter takes precedence.

accountMapperConfiguration.title: Account Mapper Configuration
accountMapperConfiguration.description:
Mapping of OAuth account to local OpenAM account

Attribute configuration that will be used to map the account of the user authenticated in the OAuth 2.0 Provider to the local data store in the OpenAM. Example: OAuth2.0_attribute=local_attribute

promptPasswordFlag.title: Prompt for password setting and activation code
promptPasswordFlag.description:
Users must set a password and complete the activation flow during dynamic profile creation.

If this is enabled, the user must set a password before the system creates an account dynamically and an activation code will be sent to the user's email address. The account will be created only if the password and activation code are properly set.
If this is disabled, the account will be created transparently without prompting the user.

smtpSslEnabled.title: SMTP SSL Enabled
smtpSslEnabled.description: Tick this option if the SMTP Server provides SSL

emailGateway.title: Mail Server Gateway implementation class
emailGateway.description:
The class used by the module to send email.

This class is used by the module to send email. A custom implementation can be provided.

The custom implementation must implement the org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.oauth2.EmailGateway

smtpHost.title: SMTP host
smtpHost.description: The mail host that will be used by the Email Gateway implementation

emailAttribute.title: Email attribute in the Response
emailAttribute.description:
Attribute from the response used to send activation code emails.

The attribute in the response from the profile service of the Provider that contains the email address of the authenticated user. This address will be used to send an email with an activation code when the accounts are allowed to be created dynamically.

smtpFromAddress.title: SMTP From address
smtpFromAddress.description: The email address on behalf of whom the messages will be sent

smtpPort.title: SMTP port
smtpPort.description: The TCP port that will be used by the SMTP gateway

smtpPassword.title: SMTP User Password
smtpPassword.description: The Password of the SMTP User Name

smtpUsername.title: SMTP User Name
smtpUsername.description: If the SMTP Service requires authentication, configure the user name here

remoteConsentResponseSigningAlg.title: Consent response signing algorithm
remoteConsentResponseSigningAlg.description: The signing algorithm to be used by the provider when verifying the signature of the consent response JWT received from the Remote Consent Service.

remoteConsentRequestEncryptionMethod.title: Consent request Encryption Method
remoteConsentRequestEncryptionMethod.description: Encryption method to be used when encrypting the consent request JWT.

remoteConsentRequestEncryptionEnabled.title: Enable consent request Encryption
remoteConsentRequestEncryptionEnabled.description: Enables encryption of the consent request JWT.

remoteConsentResponseEncryptionAlgorithm.title: Consent response encryption algorithm
remoteConsentResponseEncryptionAlgorithm.description: The encryption algorithm to be used by the provider when decrypting the remote consent response JWT received from the Remote Consent Service.

jwksUri.title: Json Web Key URI
jwksUri.description: The URI containing the public keys of the Remote Consent Service secret. The public keys are in the Json Web Key (jwk) format.

agentgroup.title: Group
agentgroup.description:
Add the agent to a group to allow inheritance of property values from the group.
Changing the group will update inherited property values.
Inherited property values are copied to the agent.

remoteConsentRequestSigningAlgorithm.title: Consent request Signing Algorithm
remoteConsentRequestSigningAlgorithm.description: Signing algorithm to be used when signing the consent request JWT.

remoteConsentResponseEncryptionMethod.title: Consent response encryption method
remoteConsentResponseEncryptionMethod.description:
The encryption method to be used by the provider when decrypting the remote consent response JWT received from the Remote Consent Service.

AM supports the following token encryption algorithms:
  • A128GCM, A192GCM, and A256GCM - AES in Galois Counter Mode (GCM) authenticated encryption mode.
  • A128CBC-HS256, A192CBC-HS384, and A256CBC-HS512 - AES encryption in CBC mode, with HMAC-SHA-2 for integrity.

jwkStoreCacheMissCacheTime.title: JWKs URI content cache miss cache time
jwkStoreCacheMissCacheTime.description: To avoid loading the JWKS URI content for every operation, especially when the kid is not in the jwks content already cached, the JWKS content will be cached for a minimum period of time. This cache miss cache time defines the minimum amount of time the JWKS URI content is cached.

jwkSet.title: Json Web Key
jwkSet.description: Raw JSON Web Key value containing the Remote Consent Service's public keys.

remoteConsentRequestEncryptionAlgorithm.title: Consent request Encryption Algorithm
remoteConsentRequestEncryptionAlgorithm.description: Encryption algorithm to be used when encrypting the consent request JWT.

remoteConsentRedirectUrl.title: Redirect URL
remoteConsentRedirectUrl.description: The Remote Consent Service's URL to which the authorization server should redirect the user in order to obtain their consent.

jwksCacheTimeout.title: JWKs URI content cache timeout in ms
jwksCacheTimeout.description: To avoid loading the JWKS URI content for every operation, the JWKS content is cached. This timeout defines the maximum amount of time the JWKS URI content can be cached before being refreshed.

userpassword.title: Remote Consent Service secret
userpassword.description: Used when the Remote Consent Service authenticates to AM.

requestTimeLimit.title: Consent Request Time Limit
requestTimeLimit.description: The amount of seconds for which the consent request JWT sent to the Remote Consent Service should be considered valid.

1.0.title: OAuth2 Remote Consent Agents
1.0.description: Agents handler that is responsible for managing agents

selfRegistrationConfirmationUrl.title: Self-Registration Confirmation Email URL
selfRegistrationConfirmationUrl.description: This page handles the HTTP GET request when the user clicks the link sent by email in the confirmation request.

selfRegistrationTokenLifetime.title: Self-Registration Token LifeTime (seconds)
selfRegistrationTokenLifetime.description: Maximum life time for the token allowing User Self-Registration using the REST API.

forgotPasswordEnabled.title: Forgot Password for Users
forgotPasswordEnabled.description: If enabled, users can assign themselves a new password using a REST API client.

forgotPasswordConfirmationUrl.title: Forgot Password Confirmation Email URL
forgotPasswordConfirmationUrl.description: This page handles the HTTP GET request when the user clicks the link sent by email in the confirmation request.

selfServiceEnabled.title: Legacy Self-Service REST Endpoint
selfServiceEnabled.description:
Specify whether to enable the legacy self-service endpoint.

OpenAM supports two User Self-Service components: the Legacy User Self-Service, which is based on a Java SDK and is available in OpenAM versions prior to OpenAM 13, and a common REST-based/XUI-based User Self-Service available in OpenAM 13 and later.

The Legacy User Self-Service will be deprecated in a future release.

selfRegistrationEnabled.title: Self-Registration for Users
selfRegistrationEnabled.description: If enabled, new users can sign up using a REST API client.

userRegisteredDestination.title: Destination After Successful Self-Registration
userRegisteredDestination.description: Specifies the behavior when self-registration has successfully completed.

protectedUserAttributes.title: Protected User Attributes
protectedUserAttributes.description: A list of user profile attributes. Users modifying any of the attributes in this list will be required to enter a password as confirmation before the change is accepted. This option applies to XUI deployments only.

forgotPasswordTokenLifetime.title: Forgot Password Token Lifetime (seconds)
forgotPasswordTokenLifetime.description: Maximum life time for the token that allows a user to process a forgotten password using the REST API.

confirmationIdHmacKey.title: Confirmation Id HMAC Signing Key
confirmationIdHmacKey.description: 256-bit key (base64-encoded) to use for HMAC signing of the legacy self-service confirmation email links.

bufferingWriterThreads.title: Writer Threads
bufferingWriterThreads.description: Specifies the number of threads used to write the buffered events.

bufferingMaxSize.title: Buffer Size (number of events)
bufferingMaxSize.description:
Size of the queue where events are buffered before they are written to the database.

This queue has to be big enough to store all incoming events that have not yet been written to the database.

If the queue reaches capacity, the process will block until a write occurs.

bufferingEnabled.title: Buffering Enabled
bufferingEnabled.description: Enables or disables audit event buffering.

bufferingWriteInterval.title: Write Interval
bufferingWriteInterval.description: Specifies the interval (seconds) at which buffered events are written to the database.

bufferingMaxBatchedEvents.title: Max Batched Events
bufferingMaxBatchedEvents.description: Specifies the maximum number of batched statements the database can support per connection.

username.title: Database Username
username.description: Specifies the username to access the database server.

maxPoolSize.title: Maximum Connections
maxPoolSize.description: Specifies the maximum number of connections in the connection pool.

databaseType.title: Database Type
databaseType.description:
Select the database to use for logging audit events.

Identifies the database in use, for example MySQL, Oracle, or SQL.

maxLifetime.title: Maximum Connection Time (seconds)
maxLifetime.description: Specifies the maximum time a JDBC connection can be open, in seconds.

connectionTimeout.title: Connection Timeout (seconds)
connectionTimeout.description: Specifies the maximum wait time before failing the connection, in seconds.

password.title: Database Password
password.description: Specifies the password to access the database server.

driverClassName.title: JDBC Driver
driverClassName.description: Fully qualified JDBC driver class name.

minIdle.title: Minimum Idle Connections
minIdle.description: Specifies the minimum number of idle connections in the connection pool.

idleTimeout.title: Maximum Connection Idle Timeout (seconds)
idleTimeout.description: Specifies the maximum idle time before the connection is closed, in seconds.

handlerFactory.title: Factory Class Name
handlerFactory.description: The fully qualified class name of the factory responsible for creating the Audit Event Handler. The class must implement org.forgerock.openam.audit.AuditEventHandlerFactory.

enabled.title: Enabled
enabled.description: Enables or disables an audit event handler.

topics.title: Topics
topics.description: List of topics handled by an audit event handler.

jwksUri.title: JWKs URI
jwksUri.description: URI to retrieve JWK verification keys from to validate the JWT signature.

allowedSubjects.title: Allowed Subjects
allowedSubjects.description: List of subjects which this provider is allowed to provide consent for. If blank then the provider can provide consent for any user in this realm.

consentedScopesClaim.title: Consented Scopes Claim
consentedScopesClaim.description: Optional claim within the JWT that lists the scopes that the user has consented to. The scopes can be represented either as a JSON array of strings, or as a single space-separated string.

issuer.title: JWT Issuer
issuer.description: Expected 'iss' claim identifier for this JWT issuer.

resourceOwnerIdentityClaim.title: Resource Owner Identity Claim
resourceOwnerIdentityClaim.description: Claim in the JWT that identifies the resource owner account in AM. Defaults to "sub".

jwkStoreCacheMissCacheTime.title: JWKs URI content cache miss cache time
jwkStoreCacheMissCacheTime.description: To avoid loading the JWKS URI content for every operation, especially when the kid is not in the jwks content already cached, the JWKS content will be cached for a minimum period of time. This cache miss cache time defines the minimum amount of time the JWKS URI content is cached.

jwksCacheTimeout.title: JWKs URI content cache timeout in ms
jwksCacheTimeout.description: To avoid loading the JWKS URI content for every operation, the JWKS content is cached. This timeout defines the maximum amount of time the JWKS URI content can be cached before being refreshed.

agentgroup.title: Group
agentgroup.description:
Add the agent to a group to allow inheritance of property values from the group.
Changing the group will update inherited property values.
Inherited property values are copied to the agent.

jwkSet.title: JWK Set
jwkSet.description: Manually entered JWK Set of verification keys to validate the JWT signature.

maxEvents.description: Maximum number of audit logs in the batch queue. Additional audit events are dropped.

sslEnabled.description:

If SSL is enabled, be sure to import the CA certificate used to sign Elasticsearch node certificates into the Java keystore on the host that runs OpenAM before attempting to log audit events to Elasticsearch.

port.description: Specifies the port number used to access Elasticsearch's REST API.

index.title: Elasticsearch Index
index.description: Specifies the name of the Elasticsearch index to be used for OpenAM audit logging.

createAccount.title: Create account if it does not exist
createAccount.description:
If the OAuth2 account does not exist in the local OpenAM data store, an account will be created dynamically.

If this is enabled, the account mapper could create the account dynamically if there is no account mapped. Before creating the account, a dialog prompting for a password and asking for an activation code can be shown if the parameter "Prompt for password setting and activation code" is enabled.

If this flag is not enabled, 3 alternative options exist:

  1. The accounts need to have a user profile in the OpenAM User Data Store
  2. The user does not have a user profile and the "Ignore Profile" is set in the Authentication Service of the realm.
  3. The account is mapped to an anonymous account (see parameter "Map to anonymous user" and "Anonymous User")

enableRegistrationService.title: Use IDM as Registration Service
enableRegistrationService.description:
Whether to use IDM as an external Registration Service to complete registration for new users.

IDM is called and passed these parameters:

  • clientToken: Signed, encrypted JWT of the OAuth 2.0 authentication state.
  • returnParams: Encoded URL parameters, required to be returned to AM to resume authentication after registration in IDM is complete.

saveAttributesInSession.title: Save attributes in the session
saveAttributesInSession.description: If this option is enabled, the attributes configured in the attribute mapper will be saved into the OpenAM session

accountProviderClass.title: Account Provider
accountProviderClass.description:
Name of the class implementing the account provider.

This class is used by the module to find the account from the attributes mapped by the Account Mapper org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.AccountProvider interface.
String constructor parameters can be provided by appending | separated values.

mapToAnonymousUser.title: Map to anonymous user
mapToAnonymousUser.description:
Enabled anonymous user access to OpenAM for OAuth authenticated users

If selected, the authenticated users in the OAuth 2.0 Provider will be mapped to the anonymous user configured in the next parameter.
If not selected the users authenticated will be mapped by the parameters configured in the account mapper.

NB If Create account if it does not exist is enabled, that parameter takes precedence.

anonymousUserName.title: Anonymous User
anonymousUserName.description:
Username of the OpenAM anonymous user

The username of the user that will represent the anonymous user. This user account must already exist in the realm.

attributeMappingClasses.title: Attribute Mapper
attributeMappingClasses.description:
Name of the class that implements the attribute mapping

This class maps the OAuth properties into OpenAM properties. A custom attribute mapper can be provided.

A custom attribute mapper must implement the org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.AttributeMapper interface.
Provided implementations are:
  • org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.JsonAttributeMapper
  • org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.oidc.JwtAttributeMapper (can only be used when using the openid scope)
String constructor parameters can be provided by appending | separated values.

accountMapperClass.title: Account Mapper
accountMapperClass.description:
Name of the class implementing the attribute mapping for the account search.

This class is used by the module to map from the account information received from the OAuth Identity Provider into OpenAM.

The class must implement the org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.AttributeMapper interface.
Provided implementations are:
  • org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.common.mapping.JsonAttributeMapper
  • org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.oidc.JwtAttributeMapper (can only be used when using the openid scope)
String constructor parameters can be provided by appending | separated values.

attributeMapperConfiguration.title: Attribute Mapper Configuration
attributeMapperConfiguration.description:
Mapping of OAuth attributes to local OpenAM attributes

Attribute configuration that will be used to map the user info obtained from the OAuth 2.0 Provider to the local user data store in the OpenAM.

Example: OAuth2.0_attribute=local_attribute

accountMapperConfiguration.title: Account Mapper Configuration
accountMapperConfiguration.description:
Mapping of OAuth account to local OpenAM account

Attribute configuration that will be used to map the account of the user authenticated in the OAuth 2.0 Provider to the local data store in the OpenAM. Example: OAuth2.0_attribute=local_attribute

userInfoEndpoint.title: User Profile Service URL
userInfoEndpoint.description:
User profile information URL

This URL endpoint provides user profile information and is provided by the OAuth Identity Provider

NB This URL should return JSON objects in response

ssoProxyUrl.title: Proxy URL
ssoProxyUrl.description:
The URL to the OpenAM OAuth proxy JSP

This URL should only be changed from the default, if an external server is performing the GET to POST proxying. The default is /openam/oauth2c/OAuthProxy.jsp

logoutBehaviour.title: Logout Options
logoutBehaviour.description:
Specify logout behavior.

The following options are available for logging out of the OAuth 2.0 Provider when the user logs out of AM:
  • prompt: Ask the user whether to log out from the OAuth 2.0 Provider
  • logout: Log out from the OAuth 2.0 Provider without asking the user
  • donotlogout: Do not log out the user from the OAuth 2.0 Provider

To enable IdP logout, you must also add org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.oauth2.OAuth2PostAuthnPlugin to the Authentication Post Processing Classes setting. Navigate to Authentication > Settings > Post Authentication Processing.

authenticationLevel.title: Authentication Level
authenticationLevel.description:
The authentication level associated with this module.

Each authentication module has an authentication level that can be used to indicate the level of security associated with the module; 0 is the lowest (and the default).

provider.title: Social Provider
provider.description: Social Provider for which this module is being setup.

logoutServiceUrl.title: OAuth 2.0 Provider Logout Service
logoutServiceUrl.description:
The URL of the Identity Provider's logout service.

To enable IdP logout, you must also add org.forgerock.openam.authentication.modules.oauth2.OAuth2PostAuthnPlugin to the Authentication Post Processing Classes setting. Navigate to Authentication > Settings > Post Authentication Processing.

clientId.title: Client Id
clientId.description:
OAuth client_id parameter

For more information on the OAuth client_id parameter refer to the RFC 6749, section 2.3.1

clientSecret.title: Client Secret
clientSecret.description:
OAuth client_secret parameter

For more information on the OAuth client_secret parameter refer to the RFC 6749, section 2.3.1

usesBasicAuth.title: Use Basic Auth
usesBasicAuth.description: When enabled, the client will use basic auth for authenticating with  the social auth provider. Enabled by default.

subjectProperty.title: Subject Property
subjectProperty.description: Property used to identify which attribute an auth server identifies a user by.

scopeDelimiter.title: Scope Delimiter
scopeDelimiter.description: Delimiter used to separate scope values. Default value is space.

scope.title: Scope
scope.description:
OAuth scope; list of user profile properties

According to the OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework, scope is a space-separated list of user profile attributes that the client application requires. The list depends on the permissions that the resource owner grants to the client application.

Some authorization servers use non-standard separators for scopes. For example, Facebook takes a comma-separated list.

tokenEndpoint.title: Access Token Endpoint URL
tokenEndpoint.description:
OAuth access token endpoint URL

This is the URL endpoint for access token retrieval provided by the OAuth Identity Provider. Refer to the RFC 6749, section 3.2

authorizeEndpoint.title: Authentication Endpoint URL
authorizeEndpoint.description:
OAuth authentication endpoint URL

This is the URL endpoint for OAuth authentication provided by the OAuth Identity Provider

secondaryRadiusServers.title: Secondary Radius Servers
secondaryRadiusServers.description:
A list of secondary Radius servers that will be used for authentication, in case the primary servers are unavailable.

The module will use secondary servers for authentication if all primary servers are unavailable. A single entry must be in the format:

radius_server:port

Multiple entries allow associations between OpenAM servers and a Radius server. The format is:

local server name | radius_server:port

NB The local server name is the full name of the server from the list of servers and sites.

primaryRadiusServers.title: Primary Radius Servers
primaryRadiusServers.description:
A list of primary Radius servers that will be used for authentication

The module will use these servers in preference to the secondary servers. A single entry must be in the format:

radius_server:port

Multiple entries allow associations between OpenAM servers and a Radius server. The format is:

local server name | radius_server:port

NB The local server name is the full name of the server from the list of servers and sites.

authenticationLevel.title: Authentication Level
authenticationLevel.description:
The authentication level associated with this module.

Each authentication module has an authentication level that can be used to indicate the level of security associated with the module; 0 is the lowest (and the default).

sharedSecret.title: Shared Secret
sharedSecret.description: The secret shared between the RADIUS server and the authentication module.

serverTimeout.title: Timeout
serverTimeout.description:
Amount of time in seconds to wait for the RADIUS server response.

This sets the SO_TIMEOUT timeout on the packet.

healthCheckInterval.title: Health check interval
healthCheckInterval.description:
The interval between checks to unavailable RADIUS servers, in minutes.

Determines how often OpenAM checks an offline server's status. The check will send an invalid authentication request to the RADIUS server. Offline servers will not be used until the healthcheck was successful. Primary servers that become available will be used in preference to secondary servers.

serverPortNumber.title: Port Number
serverPortNumber.description: Port number on which the RADIUS server is listening.

retentionMaxNumberOfHistoryFiles.title: Maximum Number of Historical Files
retentionMaxNumberOfHistoryFiles.description: Maximum number of backup audit files allowed. A value of -1 disables pruning of old history files.

retentionMaxDiskSpaceToUse.title: Maximum Disk Space
retentionMaxDiskSpaceToUse.description: The maximum amount of disk space the audit files can occupy, in bytes. A negative or zero value indicates this policy is disabled.

retentionMinFreeSpaceRequired.title: Minimum Free Space Required
retentionMinFreeSpaceRequired.description: Minimum amount of disk space required, in bytes, on the system where audit files are stored. A negative or zero value indicates this policy is disabled.

rotationFileSuffix.title: File Rotation Suffix
rotationFileSuffix.description: Suffix to append to audit files when they are rotated. Suffix should be a timestamp.

rotationMaxFileSize.title: Maximum File Size
rotationMaxFileSize.description: Maximum size, in bytes, which an audit file can grow to before rotation is triggered. A negative or zero value indicates this policy is disabled.

rotationEnabled.title: Rotation Enabled
rotationEnabled.description: Enables and disables audit file rotation.

rotationFilePrefix.title: File Rotation Prefix
rotationFilePrefix.description: Prefix to prepend to audit files when rotating audit files.

rotationInterval.title: Rotation Interval
rotationInterval.description: Interval to trigger audit file rotations, in seconds. A negative or zero value disables this feature.

rotationTimes.title: Rotation Times
rotationTimes.description: Durations after midnight to trigger file rotation, in seconds.

rotationRetentionCheckInterval.title: File Rotation Retention Check Interval
rotationRetentionCheckInterval.description: Interval to check time-based file rotation policies, in seconds.

elasticsearchCompatible.title: ElasticSearch JSON Format Compatible
elasticsearchCompatible.description: JSON format should be transformed to be compatible with  ElasticSearch format restrictions.

location.title: Log Directory
location.description: Directory in which to store audit log JSON files.

topics.title: Topics
topics.description: List of topics handled by an audit event handler.

enabled.title: Enabled
enabled.description: Enables or disables an audit event handler.

bufferingMaxSize.title: Batch Size
bufferingMaxSize.description: Maximum number of events that can be buffered (default/minimum: 100000)

bufferingWriteInterval.title: Write interval
bufferingWriteInterval.description: Interval at which buffered events are written to a file, in milliseconds.

handlerFactory.title: Factory Class Name
handlerFactory.description: The fully qualified class name of the factory responsible for creating the Audit Event Handler. The class must implement org.forgerock.openam.audit.AuditEventHandlerFactory.

enabled.description: If not enabled, prevents PKI login using the Amster module.

authorizedKeys.title: Authorized Keys
authorizedKeys.description: The location of the authorized_keys file (which has the same format as an OpenSSH authorized_keys file) to use to validate remote Amster connections.

_id.title: ID
_id.description: The identifier of the item within its type

additionalProperties.title: Other properties
additionalProperties.description: Any additional properties for the item (varies based on the schema of the type)

actions.description: Obtain the value schema for this resource.
actions.name: schema

actions.description: Obtain a template value for this resource.
actions.name: template

queries.description: Get the full list of instances of this collection. This query only supports `_queryFilter=true` filter.

knownCookieScore.title: Score
knownCookieScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

knownCookieValue.title: Cookie Value
knownCookieValue.description: The value to be set on the cookie.

invertKnownCookieScore.title: Invert Result
invertKnownCookieScore.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

knownCookieCheckEnabled.title: Cookie Value Check
knownCookieCheckEnabled.description:
Enables the checking of a known cookie value in the client request

If this check is enabled, the check looks for a known cookie in the client request. If the cookie exists and has the correct value then the check will pass.

createKnownCookieOnSuccessfulLogin.title: Save Cookie Value on Successful Login
createKnownCookieOnSuccessfulLogin.description:
The cookie will be created on the client after successful login

The Adaptive Risk Post Authentication Plug-in will set the cookie on the client response

knownCookieName.title: Cookie Name
knownCookieName.description: The name of the cookie to set on the client.

riskThreshold.title: Risk Threshold
riskThreshold.description:
If the risk threshold value is not reached after executing the different tests, the authentication is considered to be successful.

Associated with many of the adaptive risk checks is a score; if a check does not passes then the score is added to the current running total. The final score is then compared with the Risk Threshold, if the score is lesser than said threshold the module will be successful.

authenticationLevel.title: Authentication Level
authenticationLevel.description:
The authentication level associated with this module.

Each authentication module has an authentication level that can be used to indicate the level of security associated with the module; 0 is the lowest (and the default).

requestHeaderValue.title: Request Header Value
requestHeaderValue.description: The required value of the named HTTP header.

requestHeaderCheckEnabled.title: Request Header Check
requestHeaderCheckEnabled.description:
Enables the checking of the client request for a known header name and value.

The request header check will pass if the client request contains the required named header and value.

invertRequestHeaderScore.title: Invert Result
invertRequestHeaderScore.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

requestHeaderName.title: Request Header Name
requestHeaderName.description: The name of the required HTTP header

requestHeaderScore.title: Score
requestHeaderScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

ipRangeScore.title: Score
ipRangeScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

ipRangeCheckEnabled.title: IP Range Check
ipRangeCheckEnabled.description:
Enables the checking of the client IP address against a list of IP addresses.

The IP range check compares the IP of the client against a list of IP addresses, if the client IP is found within said list the check is successful.

ipRange.title: IP Range
ipRange.description:
The list of IP address to compare against the client IP address.

The format of the IP address is as follows:

  • Single IP address: 172.16.90.1
  • CIDR notation: 172.16.90.0/24
  • IP net-block with netmask: 172.16.90.0:255.255.255.0

invertIPRangeScoreEnabled.title: Invert Result
invertIPRangeScoreEnabled.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

ipHistoryProfileAttribute.title: Profile Attribute Name
ipHistoryProfileAttribute.description:
The name of the attribute used to store the IP history list in the data store.

IP history list is stored in the Data Store meaning your Data Store should be able to store values under the configured attribute name. If you're using a directory server as backend, make sure your Data Store configuration contains the necessary objectclass and attribute related settings.

saveSuccessfulIP.title: Save Successful IP Address
saveSuccessfulIP.description:
The IP History list will be updated in the data store

The Adaptive Risk Post Authentication Plug-in will update the IP history list if the overall authentication is successful.

ipHistoryCheckEnabled.title: IP History Check
ipHistoryCheckEnabled.description:
Enables the checking of client IP address against a list of past IP addresses.

If this check is enabled; a set number of past IP addresses used by the client to access OpenAM is recorded in the user profile. This check passes if the current client IP address is present in the history list. If the IP address is not present, the check fails and the IP address is added to list if the overall authentication is successful (causing the oldest IP address to be removed).

invertIPHistoryScore.title: Invert Result
invertIPHistoryScore.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

ipHistoryScore.title: Score
ipHistoryScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

ipHistoryCount.title: History size
ipHistoryCount.description: The number of client IP addresses to save in the history list.

timeSinceLastLoginScore.title: Score
timeSinceLastLoginScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

timeSinceLastLoginCookieName.title: Cookie Name
timeSinceLastLoginCookieName.description: The name of the cookie used to store the time of the last successful authentication.

timeSinceLastLoginCheckEnabled.title: Time since Last login Check
timeSinceLastLoginCheckEnabled.description:
Enables the checking of the last time the user successfully authenticated.

If this check is enabled, the check ensures the user has successfully authenticated within a given interval. If the interval has been exceeded the check will fail. The last authentication for the user is stored in a client cookie.

saveLastLoginTimeOnSuccessfulLogin.title: Save time of Successful Login
saveLastLoginTimeOnSuccessfulLogin.description:
The last login time will be saved in a client cookie

The Adaptive Risk Post Authentication Plug-in will update the last login time

maxTimeSinceLastLogin.title: Max Time since Last login
maxTimeSinceLastLogin.description: The maximum number of days that can elapse before this test.

invertTimeSinceLastLoginScore.title: Invert Result
invertTimeSinceLastLoginScore.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

invertProfileRiskAttributeScore.title: Invert Result
invertProfileRiskAttributeScore.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

profileRiskAttributeCheckEnabled.title: Profile Risk Attribute check
profileRiskAttributeCheckEnabled.description:
Enables the checking of the user profile for a matching attribute and value.

If this check is enabled, the check will pass if the users profile contains the required risk attribute and value.

profileRiskAttributeValue.title: Attribute Value
profileRiskAttributeValue.description: The required value of the named attribute.

profileRiskAttributeScore.title: Score
profileRiskAttributeScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

profileRiskAttributeName.title: Attribute Name
profileRiskAttributeName.description: The name of the attribute to retrieve from the user profile in the data store.

geolocationDatabaseLocation.title: Geolocation Database location
geolocationDatabaseLocation.description:
The path to the location of the GEO location database.

The Geolocation database is not distributed with OpenAM, you can get it in binary format from MaxMind.

invertGeolocationScore.title: Invert Result
invertGeolocationScore.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

geolocationScore.title: Score
geolocationScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

geolocationValidCountryCodes.title: Valid Country Codes
geolocationValidCountryCodes.description:
The list of country codes that are considered as valid locations for client IPs.

The list is made up of country codes separated by a | character; for example:

gb|us|no|fr

geolocationCheckEnabled.title: Geolocation Country Code Check
geolocationCheckEnabled.description:
Enables the checking of the client IP address against the geolocation database.

The geolocation database associates IP addresses against their known location. This check passes if the country associated with the client IP address is matched against the list of valid country codes.

The geolocation database is available in binary format at MaxMind.

deviceCookieScore.title: Score
deviceCookieScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

saveDeviceCookieValueOnSuccessfulLogin.title: Save Device Registration on Successful Login
saveDeviceCookieValueOnSuccessfulLogin.description:
Set the device cookie on the client response

The Adaptive Risk Post Authentication Plug-in will set the device cookie on the client response

deviceCookieName.title: Cookie Name
deviceCookieName.description: The name of the cookie to be checked for (and optionally set) on the client request

invertDeviceCookieScore.title: Invert Result
invertDeviceCookieScore.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

deviceCookieCheckEnabled.title: Device Registration Cookie Check
deviceCookieCheckEnabled.description:
Enables the checking of the client request for a known cookie.

If this check is enabled, the check will pass if the client request contains the named cookie.

failureScore.title: Score
failureScore.description: The amount to increment the score if this check fails.

invertFailureScore.title: Invert Result
invertFailureScore.description: If the check succeeds the score will be included in the total, for failure the score will not be incremented.

failedAuthenticationCheckEnabled.title: Failed Authentication Check
failedAuthenticationCheckEnabled.description:
Checks if the user has past authentication failures.

Check if the OpenAM account lockout mechanism has recorded past authentication failures for the user.

NB For this check to function, Account Lockout must be enabled.

actions.description: Obtain the collection of all secondary configuration types related to the resource.
